PREFACE
This Code of the City of Des Plaines, as supplemented, contains ordinances up
to and including ordinance M-10-25, passed April 21, 2025, ordinance T-9-09,
passed July 20, 2009, and ordinance Z-3-25, passed March 3, 2025. Ordinances of
the City adopted after said ordinances supersede the provisions of this Code to
the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the
City office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the Code
has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

ORDINANCE   M -21-24
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING THE DES PLAINES CITY CODE TO REFLECT THE PLANNED
DISSOLUTION OF THE WHEELING/DES PLAINES JOINT EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEMS
BOARD.        
WHEREAS, the City of Des Plaines
(“City”) is a home rule municipal corporation in accordance with Article VII,
Section 6(a) of the Constitution of the State of Illinois of 1970; and
 
WHEREAS,  Chapter 13 of Title 1 of the City Code of Des Plaines (“ City Code ”)
entitled “Emergency Telephone Answering System,” establishes the authorizes the
City to operate an emergency telephone system (“ 9-1-1   System ”) and
designates that the 91-1 System will be administered by a Joint Emergency
Telephone System Board (“ JETSB ”) established pursuant to an intergovernmental
agreement;  and
 
WHEREAS, the City’s JETSB is governed by that certain "Amended and Restated
Intergovernmental Agreement Establishing a Joint Emergency Telephone Systems
Board" by sand between the City of Des Plaines (" Des Plaines "), and the
Village of Wheeling (“ Wheeling ”) (collectively and individually, the " Member
Municipalities ") dated July 17, 2017 (" Intergovernmental Agreement ") and by-
laws duly adopted; and
WHEREAS, Des Plaines has submitted a notice to Wheeling of its intent to
terminate the Intergovernmental Agreement and leave the JETSB in accordance
with the procedures set forth in Section 9 of the Intergovernmental Agreement;
and
WHEREAS, with the termination of Des Plaines’ participation in the JETSB, the
JETSB will be dissolved; and
WHEREAS, pursuant to Resolution R-208-23, the City has entered into an
intergovernmental agreement with the County of Cook for the County to provide
dispatch services for the City (“ Dispatch IGA ”); and
WHEREAS, pursuant to the Dispatch IGA, the Cook County Sheriff’s Office will
process 9-1-1 calls and provide other services for the 9-1-1 System, including
call taking, dispatching and radio monitoring as operated by the Cook County
Emergency Telephone System Board (“ County ETSB ”); and
WHEREAS, pursuant Resolution R-171-24, the City will enter into an
intergovernmental agreement with the County ETSB to allow for the disbursement
of 911 surcharges collected by the State of Illinois and attributable to users
of the City’s 9-1-1 System to the County ETSB (“ Surcharge Distribution IGA ”);
and
WHEREAS, pursuant to Resolution R-178-24, the City and Wheeling will enter into
a Wind-Down and Termination Agreement for the Wheeling Des Plaines JETSB (“
Wind-Down and Termination Agreement ”); and
WHEREAS, the City Council has determined that it is appropriate to amend the
language of Chapter 13 to reflect the dissolution of the JETSB and the City’s
transition to the County ETSB; 
 
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the City Council of the City of Des
Plaines, Cook County, Illinois, in the exercise of its home rule
powers, as follows:
 
SECTION 1: RECITALS.  The foregoing recitals are incorporated into,
and made a part of, this Ordinance as the findings of the City Council.
 
SECTION 2: AMENDMENT.  Chapter 13, “Emergency Telephone Answering System – 9-1-
1,” of Title 1, “Administration,” of the City Code is hereby amended in its
entirety and shall be and read as follows: [Deleted Language is Struck Through.
New Language is Bolded and Double Underlined.]
 
1-13-1: AUTHORITY:
 
This chapter is enacted under the authority of the emergency telephone system
act, 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 750/0.01 et seq.
 
1-13-2: PURPOSE:
 
This chapter is enacted for the purpose of authorizing the operations of
 creating a joint emergency telephone answering system. The intent of this
system is to allow any telephone located within the city of Des Plaines and
connected to the public telephone network access to emergency services by
dialing the numbers 9-1-1.
 
1-13-3: AVAILABILITY:
 
The features offered by the emergency telephone answering system shall be
available twenty four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week.
 
1-13-4: ADMINISTRATION:
 
The city’s emergency telephone answering system shall  may be administered by a
joint emergency telephone system board ("JETSB") established pursuant to an
intergovernmental agreement with any agency authorized by the Illinois Commerce
Commission to operate an emergency telephone system and an emergency telephone
system board  approved by a duly adopted resolution of the city council.
 
1-13-5: FUNDING:
 
If authorized by 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 750/15.3, the city of Des
Plaines shall impose a surcharge on monthly billed subscribers of
telecommunication carriers at a rate per network connection in order to
implement and maintain a 9-1-1 emergency telephone system.
 
A surcharge is hereby imposed on monthly billed subscribers of
telecommunications carriers residing within the corporate limits of the city at
a rate of zero dollars ($0.00) per month, per network connection. Said
surcharge shall be collected by the telecommunications carriers. For purposes
of computing the surcharge imposed, the network connections to which the
surcharge shall apply shall be those in-service network connections, other than
those network connections assigned to the city, where the subscriber service
address for each such network connection(s) is located within the corporate
limits of the city.
 
Sections 1-13-6 through 1-13-10 are repealed and reserved for future use.
 
1-13-11: SEVERABILITY:
 
If any section, provision or portion of this chapter shall be adjudged invalid
by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter shall not
be affected thereby.
 
SECTION 2: EFFECTIVE DATE.  This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect
from and after its passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form according
to law but only after the Migration Dates of both Des Plaines and Wheeling as
defined in the Wind-Down and Termination Agreement have both occurred.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE M-67-02
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE CITY OF DES PLAINES CITY CODE
   BE IT ORDAINED by the City Council of the City of Des Plaines, Cook County,
Illinois, in the exercise of its home rule powers, as follows:
   Section 1: Pursuant to its home rule authority under the provisions of 65
ILCS 5/1-2-3 (2000), the Illinois Constitution, and the Code of Civil
Procedures 735 ILCS 5/8-1104 (2000), and from and after the date of passage of
this ordinance, the City Code of the City of Des Plaines, Illinois, prepared by
Sterling Codifiers, Inc. containing the compilation of all ordinances of a
general nature together with the changes made to said ordinances, under the
direction of the governing body of the City, shall be admissible in all courts
and hearings as the official code and law of the City as enacted by the Mayor
and City Council.
   Section 2: There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification,
the loose-leaf type of binding together with the continuous supplement service,
provided by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., their successors or assigns, or any other
codifier selected by the City, whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a
general and permanent nature amending, altering, adding or deleting provisions
of the official City Code is identified by the proper catchline and is inserted
in the proper place in each of the official copies, one copy of which shall be
maintained in the office of the City Clerk, certified as to correctness and
available for inspection at any and all times that said office is regularly
open.
   Section 3: All ordinances of a general nature included in this official City
Code shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provision and the
fact that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the governing
body shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous effectiveness
of ordinances included in said official City Code. All ordinances of a special
nature, such as tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances, franchises, vacating
ordinances and annexation ordinances shall continue in full force and effect
unless specifically repealed or amended by a provision of the City Code. Such
ordinances are not intended to be included in the official City Code.
   Section 4: Only the City Council by duly adopted ordinance may add or delete
portions of this Code. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation
to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code,
or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with
such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City to be
misrepresented thereby.
   Section 5: All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are,
to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed.
   Section 6: That this Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and
after its passage, approval and publication in pamphlet form according to law.
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
DES PLAINES CITY CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Interpretations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the governing body, this city code is hereby declared to be
and shall hereafter constitute the official city code of the city of Des
Plaines. Any reference made to the number of any section contained herein shall
be understood to refer to the position of the same under its appropriate
chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty clause relating thereto,
as well a to the section itself, when reference is made to this city code by
title in any legal document. (1963 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This city code shall hereafter be received without further proof in all courts
and in all administrative tribunals of this state as the ordinances of the city
of general and permanent effect, pursuant to the provisions of 735 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-1203. (2002 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this city code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute a sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendments or revisions by ordinance of any part of this city code. All
such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to
Sterling Codifiers, Inc., or their successors as determined by the city
council. Said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in its proper
place in each copy of this city code. Each such replacement shall be properly
identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of the city code.
(1963 Code)
1-1-4: INTERPRETATIONS:
In the determination of the provisions of each section of this city code, the
following rules shall be observed:
   A.   Liability Of Employers And Agents: When the provisions of any section
of this city code prohibits the commission of an act, not only the person
actually doing the prohibited act or omitting the directed act, but also the
employer and all other persons concerned with or in aiding or abetting the said
person shall be guilty of the offense described and liable to the penalty set
forth. (1963 Code)
   B.   Liberal Construction: The provisions of this city code are to be
liberally construed to accomplish the intent of the city council to regulate,
promote and protect the general health, safety and welfare of the city and of
the citizens of Des Plaines. (2002 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Adoption Of Code
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability
1-2-1: ADOPTION OF CODE:
All general ordinances of the city passed prior to the adoption of this city
code are hereby repealed, except such as are referred to herein as being still
in force or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject
to the saving clauses contained in the following section), from which are
excluded the following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy
ordinances; appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and
annexations; franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights
to persons or corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the
execution of a contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances;
ordinances establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public
places; improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to
elections; ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by
or from the city; and all special ordinances. (1963 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other
public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be repealed by virtue of the adoption of this city code or by
virtue of the preceding Section, excepting as this city code may contain
provisions for such matters, in which case this city code shall be considered
as amending such ordinance or ordinances in respect to such provisions only.
(1963 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance,
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform to the
ordinance in force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If
any penalty, forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new
ordinance, such provision may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied
to any judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this or the preceding section shall be construed as
abating any action now pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of
the city herein repealed; or as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering
any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any person,
firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the city under any ordinance or
provision thereof in force at the time of the adoption of this city code. (1963
Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or
other part of this city code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of
the remaining portions of this code, or any part thereof. The mayor and city
council hereby declare that they would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or other part thereof
irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections, subsections,
subdivisions, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, phrases or other parts be
declared unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (2002 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions
1-3-3: Fiscal Year
1-3-4: Official Time
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this city code uses the plural tense in
describing or referring to any matter, parties or persons, all persons in that
section are included although not individually named or referred to.
When any subject matter, party or person is referred to in this city code by
words importing the masculine gender, females as well as males and bodies
corporate, shall be deemed to be included. Provided, that these rules of
construction shall not be applied to any section of this city code which
contains any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject
matter or content may be repugnant thereto. (1963 Code; amd. 2002 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another.
CITY: The city of Des Plaines, Illinois.
CODE: Unless otherwise specifically stated, shall mean this city code.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city employee by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Des Plaines".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the city for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation, or for any permit, license or other charge required
or imposed by the city.
KNOWINGLY: With knowledge, consciously, intelligently and/or intentionally. It
does not require any knowledge of the unlawfulness of such act or omission.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense deemed a violation of the provisions of this code
which is a lesser offense than a felony, as defined by state law.
NEGLIGENT: Together with the words "neglect", "negligence" and "negligently",
imports a want of such attention to the nature or probable consequences of the
act or omission as a prudent man ordinarily bestows in acting in his own
concern.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the city; or any act or thing repugnant to,or creating a hazard
to, or having a detrimental effect on, the property of another person or to the
community.
OCCUPANT: Applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land whether alone or with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provisions of this code or the omission of
any act required by the provisions of this code, state or federal law.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this code to a city officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the city of
Des Plaines".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of or managing any operation, business or
profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner,
tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of such
building or land.
PERSON: Includes the singular and the plural and shall also mean and include
any person, firm, corporation, association, partnership or any other form of
association or organization.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every description of money, goods, chattels,
effects, evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any
pecuniary obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged,
transferred, increased, defeated, discharged or diminished, and every right or
interest therein.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in various quantities
direct to the consumer.
STREET: Includes alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public ways, public squares
and public places.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies
the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or with others.
WHOLESALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to
relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to
persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WILFULLY: As applied to the intent with which an act is done or omitted,
implies simply a purpose or willingness to commit the act or make the omission
referred to. It does not require any intent to violate law, or to injure
another, or to acquire an advantage. (1963 Code; amd. 2002 Code)
1-3-3: FISCAL YEAR:
The fiscal year of the city shall commence on January 1 of each and every year
1
. (Ord. M-16-95, 4-3-1995)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  3-4-3A of this code.
1-3-4: OFFICIAL TIME:
Central standard time shall hereafter be the official time within the city for
the transaction of all city business, except that at two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on
the first Sunday of April in each year, official time for the city shall be
advanced one hour, and at two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the last Sunday of October
of the year, the official time shall, by retarding of the same one hour, be
returned to central standard time; and all legal or official proceedings of the
city council and all official business of the city shall be regulated thereby,
and when, by ordinance, resolution or action by any municipal officer or body,
an act must be performed at or within a prescribed time, it shall be done
according to official time. (Ord. M-39-96, 8-5-1996; amd. 2002 Code)
All clocks or other timepieces in or upon public buildings or other premises
maintained at the expense of the city shall be set and run according to the
official time provided in this section, and it is hereby made the duty of the
officer or other person having control and charge of such buildings and
premises to see that the clocks or other timepieces are set and run in
accordance with the official time as provided by this section.
All persons residing within the city and all persons doing business within the
city are hereby requested to set and run any clocks or other timepieces under
their control in accordance with the official time as provided in this section
1
. (Ord. M-39-96, 8-5-1996)
 
Notes
1 2. 5 ILCS 440/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: License Revocation
1-4-3: Application Of Provisions
1-4-4: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code, unless
otherwise specified, shall be fined a sum not to exceed seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense. The penalty provision of this section shall
be automatically applicable to and included in any ordinance that amends,
corrects or adds to any title, chapter or section of this code 1
. (Ord. M-23-81, 5-4-1981; amd. 2002 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.
1-4-2: LICENSE REVOCATION:
When a person is convicted of a violation of any section of this code, any
license previously issued to him by the city may be revoked as provided for in
this code if he has been convicted of, pled guilty to or been found guilty by a
court of law of a felony or an offense involving moral turpitude. (1963 Code;
amd. 2002 Code)
1-4-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where any duty
is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any act which is of a continuing
nature or declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day such duty or
obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of the city code and there shall be no fine
or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this
chapter shall apply and a separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each
day during or on which a breach or violation occurs or continues. (1963 Code)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee or
a licensee shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for
any fine or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the
intention of the city council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (1963 Code)
CHAPTER 5
MAYOR 1
SECTION:
1-5-1: Qualifications
1-5-2: Powers And Duties
1-5-3: Mayor Pro Tem
1-5-4: Acting Mayor
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1-7-5 of this title for mayor's compensation.
1-5-1: QUALIFICATIONS:
The mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the city; he shall be a
citizen of the United States, a qualified elector, reside within the city
limits, and shall hold office for four (4) years and until his successor is
elected and qualified unless hereafter otherwise provided by law. (1956 Code
ch. 1)
1-5-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   General Powers: The mayor shall devote so much of his time to the
duties of his office as a faithful and efficient discharge thereof may require.
Furthermore, he shall take care that all the provisions of this code and other
laws of the city are properly enforced and observed; he shall preside at all
meetings of the city council, but shall not vote on any ordinance, resolution
or motion, except:
      1.   Where the vote of the aldermen has resulted in a tie; or
      2.   Where one-half (1/2) of the aldermen elected have voted in favor of
an ordinance, resolution or motion, even though there is no tie vote; or
      3.   Where a vote greater than the majority of the corporate authorities
is required by statute to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. (Ord. M-47-
81, 8-17-1981)
   B.   Mayoral Appointments: The mayor shall submit all aldermanic and
commission appointments to the city council at the regular city council meeting
prior to the regular city council meeting at which ratification is to be
considered. (Ord. M-27-80, 7-7-1980)
   C.   Signatures; Contracts Of City: Except as otherwise expressly provided,
the mayor shall sign all commissions, licenses, permits and warrants issued or
drawn by order of the city council, or authorized by the provisions of this
code; in all contracts where the city is a party, he shall sign the same on
behalf of the city; and in all suits where the city is a party, it shall be his
duty to advise with and assist the city attorney in the prosecution or defense
of same, as the case may be. (1956 Code ch. 1; amd. 2002 Code)
   D.   Conservator Of The Peace; Release Prisoners: The mayor may exercise,
within the city limits, the power conferred upon him by law to suppress
disorder and keep the peace; and he may release any person imprisoned for
violation of any provision of this code, and shall report such release with the
cause thereof to the city council at its first session thereafter.
   E.   Additional Powers: In addition to the foregoing, the mayor shall
perform all such other duties and have all additional powers that are or may be
prescribed by the laws of the state, or the provisions of this code. (1956 Code
ch. 1)
1-5-3: MAYOR PRO TEM:
If a temporary absence or disability of the mayor incapacitates him from the
performance of his duties but does not create a vacancy in the office, the city
council shall elect one of its members to act as mayor pro tem. During this
absence or disability, the mayor pro tem shall perform the duties and possess
all the rights and powers of the mayor. Nothing in this section shall deprive
the mayor pro tem from voting in his capacity as alderman, but he shall not be
entitled to another vote in his capacity as mayor pro tem. (1956 Code ch. 1)
1-5-4: ACTING MAYOR:
If a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor, and the vacancy occurs with less
than twenty eight (28) months remaining in the unexpired portion of the mayoral
term or less than one hundred thirty (130) days before the general municipal
election, then the city council shall fill the vacancy by electing one of its
members as acting mayor, who shall serve as acting mayor until a mayor is
elected at the next general municipal election and has qualified, or until such
earlier time as determined by the city council at the time of the election of
the acting mayor. Nothing in this section shall deprive the acting mayor from
voting in his or her capacity as alderman, but the acting mayor shall not be
entitled to another vote in the capacity as acting mayor. (Ord. M-2-13, 1-22-
2013)
CHAPTER 6
CITY COUNCIL
SECTION:
1-6-1: Members And Terms
1-6-2: Election Procedures
1-6-3: Meetings
1-6-3-1: Meeting Procedures
1-6-4: Committees Of The City Council
1-6-5: Ordinance Procedures
1-6-1: MEMBERS AND TERMS:
The city council shall consist of eight (8) aldermen and the mayor.
The city council shall convene at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M., on the date of the
first regular meeting of the city council in May following the canvass of votes
after a city election and conclude any unfinished business still before it. The
terms of office of the mayor, city clerk and aldermen, whose offices may have
been up for election, shall commence at eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. or as soon
after the unfinished business of the sitting city council may have concluded.
(Ord. M-11-05, 3-21-2005)
1-6-2: ELECTION PROCEDURES:
The election of any aldermen may be contested by any elector of the city, and
the proceedings shall, except as herein provided, be in accordance with the
general laws of the state 1
. (Ch. 2, 1956 Code; amd. 2002 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 10 ILCS 5/23-1 et seq.
1-6-3: MEETINGS:
   A.   General: All meetings of the mayor and city council, and all committees
thereof, shall be conducted as provided by state law and the Illinois Open
Meetings Act, and under the procedures set out in this section.
   B.    Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the city council shall be
held on the first and third Mondays of each month at the hour of seven o’clock
(7:00) P.M. at the Bertha Eleanor Rohrbach memorial council room in the civic
center, or at such other time and place within the limits of the city as the
mayor and city council may from time to time direct. If the day of a regular
city council meeting falls on a holiday on which the civic center is closed for
a city recognized holiday, then the city council shall meet at the same hour on
the next day which is not a holiday. However, the city council may determine to
hold its regular meeting on a holiday if so authorized by a vote of two-thirds
(2/3) of all aldermen then holding office.
   C.   General Structure of Regular Meetings: The regular meeting of the city
council shall include consideration of ordinances, resolutions, and other
matters before the council. The mayor shall direct the appropriate committee
chair to lead the council’s consideration of matters within the jurisdiction of
that chair’s committee. The mayor shall remain the presiding officer,
including, without limitation, for all votes of the council. The council may
convene at any time as the committee of the whole for general discussions on
matters initiated by the council, the mayor, or the city staff. The committee
of the whole may consider and make recommendations to be reported out to the
city council for action. Final action on all matters may only take place during
meetings of the city council and not when the city council is convened as the
committee of the whole.
   D.   Special Meetings: Special meetings of the city council may be called by
the mayor or any three (3) aldermen whenever they may deem it necessary. The
mayor or aldermen calling such meeting shall file with the city clerk a
statement in writing, setting forth the purpose of such special meeting and
directing the city clerk to give notice of the same. Upon the filing of said
statement, the city clerk shall cause to be served personally upon each member
of the city council, or left at his or her usual place of residence, at least
twenty four (24) hours before the time of such meeting, a notice thereof
setting forth the purpose of such special meeting and the time of holding same.
   E.   Quorum: A majority of the corporate authorities shall constitute a
quorum to do business, but a smaller number may adjourn from time to time and
may compel the attendance of absentees, under the penalties prescribed by
subsection F of this section.
   F.   Compelling Attendance: In case of the absence of a quorum at any time
of a city council meeting, a majority of the aldermen present may direct the
mayor, or presiding officer, to direct any City police officer to go out and
notify any and all absent members that can be found in the city, who are not
unable through sickness, to attend, and if upon notice and request by the
officer any such member shall refuse to attend, the officer shall, without
warrant, arrest the member and bring the member to the meeting.
   G.   Voting Required: Every member of the city council shall vote on all
questions for which a vote is called or taken by the city council, except a
member of the city council shall not vote on any matter when prohibited from
doing so pursuant to applicable provisions of Illinois statutes or the City’s
Code of Ethics (Title I, Chapter 9 of the City Code). (1956 Code ch. 2; amd. 1-
6-1958; Ord. M-24-93, 6-7-1993; 2002 Code; Ord. M-7-03, 2-18-2003)
1-6-3-1: MEETING PROCEDURES:
   A.   General. The current edition of “Robert’s Rules Of Order” shall govern
the proceedings of the city council, except where they conflict with the rules
set forth in this Code, in which case the rules set forth in this Code shall
apply to the extent of the conflict. These rules may be temporarily suspended
by either the unanimous consent of the members present or by a two-thirds (2/3)
vote of all the members elected to the city council.
      Rule 1.   The mayor shall take the chair at the hour appointed, or to
which the city council shall have adjourned, and shall immediately call the
members to order; whereupon the city clerk (or someone appointed to fill the
clerk’s place) shall proceed to call the roll of members, marking the members
present and absent for inclusion in the minutes. If a quorum is present, the
mayor shall so announce and the city council shall proceed with the order of
business.
      Rule 2.    At any meeting of the city council where a quorum shall be
assembled, and if the mayor is absent, the city clerk shall initially preside
and call the roll, whereupon the city council shall elect a mayor pro tem from
its membership to chair the meeting.
      Rule 3.    The City Manager shall be primarily responsible for
establishing and posting the agenda for city council meetings in accordance
with the Illinois Open Meetings Act. At the direction of the Mayor or any three
Alderman, items may be placed on a City Council agenda.
      Rule 4.    All questions relating to the priority of business shall be
decided without debate.
      Rule 5.    The mayor shall preserve order and decorum; may speak upon and
decide all questions of order, subject to an appeal to the city council; and
shall conduct all business before the city council with fairness and
impartiality to a speedy and proper result.
      Rule 6. Every member, prior to speaking or presenting any matter to the
city council, shall address the matter to the chair, and shall not proceed
until recognized by the chair.
      Rule 7. The Chair will attempt to ensure that all members will be given
an opportunity to speak on a matter prior to any member speaking more than once
on the matter.
      Rule 8.    A member called to order shall immediately stop speaking,
unless permitted to explain. If there is no appeal, the decision of the chair
shall be conclusive; but if the member appeals to the city council from the
decision of the chair, the city council shall decide the matter, and the
question to be put shall be, “Shall the decision of the chair be sustained?”.
      Rule 9. No motion shall be debated or put unless it is seconded. When a
motion is seconded, it shall be stated by the chair or read by the city clerk
before a vote.
      Rule 10. After a motion is stated by the chair, it shall be deemed to be
in possession of the city council, but may be withdrawn at any time by the
maker thereof, together with the consent of the second, before a vote or
amendment.
      Rule 11. If the question in debate contains several distinct
propositions, any member may, up   on request, have the same divided, except
that an ordinance shall be considered as a single proposition, not subject to
division.
      Rule 12. When a blank is to be filled, and different sums or times are
proposed, the question shall first be put upon the smallest sum and the longest
time.
      Rule 13. When a motion has been made and seconded and is before the city
council, no motion shall be received, except as herein specified, and which
shall have precedence in the order herein stated.
         1.   To fix the time to which to adjourn.
         2.   To adjourn.
         3.   To take a recess.
         4.   To raise a question of privilege.
         5.   To call for the orders of the day.
         6.   To lay on the table.
         7.   To call for the previous question. (2/3 vote of Council)
         8.   To limit or extend limits of debates. (2/3 vote of Council)
         9.   To postpone to a certain time.
         10.   To commit or refer.
         11.   To amend.
         12.   To postpone indefinitely.
      Rule 14. The motion to adjourn or to lay on the table shall be decided
without debate, and the motion to fix the time to which to adjourn and the
motion to adjourn shall always be in order, except:
         1.   When a member is in possession of the floor.
         2.   While the members are voting.
         3.   When it has been decided that the “previous question” shall be
taken.
      Rule 15. A motion to adjourn cannot be amended; but a motion to adjourn
to a given day or time shall be open to amendment and debate.
      Rule 16. When a question is postponed indefinitely, it shall not be taken
up again before the next regular meeting.
      Rule 17. A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but a motion
to amend an amendment to an amendment shall not be in order.
      Rule 18. When amendments are offered to any motion before the city
council, the vote shall first be taken on the amendment last proposed.
      Rule 19. An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in
order, but an amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.
      Rule 20. In all cases where a motion shall be entered in the minutes of
the city council, the name of the member moving the same, together with that of
the second, shall also be entered on the minutes.
      Rule 21. The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of all
ordinances, and all propositions to create a liability against the city or for
the expenditure or appropriation of its money, and in all other cases at the
request of any member, which yeas and nays shall be entered upon the minutes,
and a concurrence of a majority of all members elected to the city council
shall be necessary to the final passage of any such ordinance or proposition.
      Rule 22. All motions referring any matter to a standing or special
committee or to staff shall specify the issues to be considered by the
committee or staff.
      Rule 23. All communications, petitions, reports or any other papers
addressed to the city council, shall be filed with the city clerk, presented to
the mayor and the city council and then referred to staff for review. The staff
shall report back to the city council on the subject matter thereof.
      Rule 24. Unless otherwise limited by applicable law, a motion to
reconsider (“Reconsider Motion”) shall be in order at the same meeting at which
the vote to be reconsidered (“Underlying Matter”) was taken or at the next city
council meeting. If the Reconsider Motion passes at the same meeting at which
the vote on the Underlying Matter was taken, the Underlying Matter can be voted
on at that same meeting or at a subsequent city council meeting. If the
Reconsider Motion passes at the city council meeting after the meeting at which
the vote on the Underlying Matter was taken, then the Underlying Matter shall
be put on the agenda for the first city council meeting following passage of
the Reconsider Motion. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Rule,
no vote on the Underlying Matter shall be taken at any special meeting unless
at such special meeting there are present as many aldermen as were present at
the meeting at which the vote on the Underlying Matter was initially taken. A
Reconsider Motion may only be made by a member of the city council who voted
with the prevailing side on the Underlying Matter.
      Rule 25. Audience members who wish to address the council about an agenda
item under consideration will have an opportunity to make comments and ask
questions after presentations by the city staff and the interested parties.
Audience members who wish to make comments about any matter not on the agenda
for council consideration may do so only during the “Public Comment” portion of
the agenda. The following specific rules and procedures apply to all public
comment, whether made during a scheduled agenda item or during the “Public
Comment” portion of the agenda:
         25.1   The Mayor will ask if anyone wishes to address the Council on a
matter and will determine the order in which speakers will be recognized.
         25.2   As the Mayor recognizes an audience member who wishes to speak,
the speaker will rise and go to the microphone. The Mayor may ask each speaker
to state his or her name, address and group affiliation, if any, but no speaker
shall be required to state his or her address.
         25.3   Each speaker shall speak clearly into the microphone.
         25.4   All speakers shall address their comments to the Council, and
not to other members of the audience.
         25.5   Statements should be kept as brief, to the point, and non-
repetitive as possible.
         25.6   An immediate response, discussion or debate on public comments
shall not be required of the Council or any member of the Council.
         25.7   Unless an exception is granted by the Mayor or the Council,
each person will be allowed up to five minutes to speak. No person will be
allowed to speak a second time on the same matter until all people who wish to
speak on that matter have been allowed to do so. The Council may end public
comment.
         25.8   Public comments shall not be discourteous, belligerent,
impertinent, threatening, disparaging, or otherwise uncivil. No person shall
interrupt the proceedings of the Council or cause any other form of disturbance
or disruption.
         25.9   Any person acting or appearing in a lewd or disgraceful manner,
or who uses opprobrious, obscene or insulting language to or about the mayor or
any member of the city council or anybody in attendance, or who does not obey
the orders of the mayor, shall be expelled from the meeting by the mayor;
provided that a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the city council may overturn the
decision of the chair to expel. By a vote of two-thirds of the city council any
such person may be expelled from the meeting, and by a majority vote of the
council present may be censured.
         25.10   When the city council is sitting as the committee of the
whole, the rules for public comment set forth in this Rule 25 shall apply.
         25.11   Rules 25.1 through 25.10 concerning public comment and
participation apply to all public bodies in the City unless a public body
adopts, or has adopted, more specific rules and procedures that provide
additional opportunities for public comment and participation, in which case
the more specific rules and procedures control. When Rules 25.1 through 25.10
are applied to a public body other than the city council, references to the
council and the mayor will be deemed to be references to the public body and
its chair, respectively. Further, references to the mayor will be deemed to
include the appropriate committee chair leading council consideration under
Subsection 1-6-3.C of these Rules.
      Rule 26. The mayor pro tem when selected from the city council, shall not
be deprived of his or her right to vote or debate, but shall have only one vote
on each matter.
      Rule 27. Whenever a question is laid on the table, it remains there until
taken from the table and the question does not die if not taken from the table
within any time limit.
      Rule 29. Whenever any alderman elects to abstain from voting on any
question which comes before the city council for its action, the alderman shall
be required to give an explanation for the abstention.
      Rule 30. Upon the request of any two aldermen present, any report of a
committee of the city council shall be deferred for final action to the next
regular meeting of the city council after the report is made.
      Rule 31. The “consent agenda” shall be the equivalent of the “omnibus
vote” as provided in 65 ILCS 5/3.1-40-40. A favorable vote on a motion to
approve the consent agenda shall constitute approval of all of the matters
included on the consent agenda. The mayor, city clerk, any alderman, or any
resident of Des Plaines may direct that an item be removed from the consent
agenda. Any item removed shall be considered separately, following the
conclusion of the vote on the consent agenda. (1956 Code ch. 2; amd. Ord. M-11-
03, 2-18-2003)
1-6-4: COMMITTEES OF THE CITY COUNCIL:
   A.   Standing Committees: The following shall be the standing committees of
the city council:
      Building Code
      Community Development
      Community Services
      Engineering
      Finance and Administration
      Legal and Licensing
      Public Safety
      Public Works
   B.   Composition of Standing Committees. Each Standing Committee shall
consist of three aldermen as selected pursuant to Subsection C of this Section.
Each Committee shall be comprised of a chair, a vice chair, and one other
member. The mayor and the remaining aldermen shall have the right to attend any
meeting of a standing committee and to participate in discussion, but shall not
be members of the committee. No alderman will serve as chair of more than one
committee. No alderman will serve as vice chair of more than one committee.
   C.   Committee on Committees. At the first regular meeting after a City
election, the city council shall appoint a chair for a committee known as the
“committee on committees” which shall be a committee of the whole. A date for a
meeting of the committee on committees shall be set between the first and
second regular city council meetings after a City election. The committee shall
meet and prepare a recommendation of appointments and designation of chairs and
vice chairs and members for the standing committees. At the next regular
meeting of the City council, the committee on committees shall submit a
recommended resolution to the City council designating the chairs, vice chairs,
and members of the standing committees. The City council shall, by a majority
vote of the City council, adopt a resolution designating the chairs, vice
chairs, and members of the standing committees. The standing committee
assignments shall be for two years.
   D.   Special Committees. The mayor may appoint such special committees as he
may consider necessary from time to time with the consent of a majority vote of
the city council. Each special committee shall be automatically dissolved after
three months from the date of establishment, unless the special committee is
extended by a majority vote of the city council.
   E.   Committee Duties. Each committee, whether standing or special, shall
promptly and thoroughly investigate and report to the mayor and city council
upon all matters referred to it by the city council, and shall attach to its
report all staff documents in the possession of the committee relating thereto,
and do and perform such other and further duties as the mayor and city council
may, from time to time, prescribe.
   F.   Mayor. The mayor shall be an ex officio member of each standing and
special committee, entitled to attend, participate in discussion, but not to
vote in committee.
   G.   Committee Matters: The chair of a committee may place an item for
consideration on that committee’s agenda by making a request to the city
clerk’s office by twelve o’clock (12:00) noon on the Monday preceding the day
for distribution of the packet of information for the city council. (Ord. M-24-
93, 6-7-1993; amd. Ord. M-32-99, 6-21-1999; 2002 Code)
1-6-5: ORDINANCE PROCEDURES:
   A.   First And Second Reading: All ordinances shall be in writing. The city
manager shall number each proposed ordinance and place it on the agenda of a
city council meeting. The agenda shall include the ordinance number and a brief
description of the subject matter of the ordinance. An ordinance may be
approved on first reading by a majority of the city council present at the
meeting. If an ordinance is approved on first reading, the ordinance shall
advance to second reading. The city clerk shall place the ordinance on the
agenda of the next city council meeting. No ordinance may be adopted unless it
has been advanced to and approved on second reading by the city council.
Adoption of an ordinance on second reading requires the concurrence of a
majority of the city council; provided, however, that an ordinance may be
advanced to second reading for adoption at the same meeting at which first
reading was approved only upon a vote of no less than five members of the city
council or two-thirds of the corporate authorities present, whichever is
greater.
   B.   City Council Reconsideration; Passing Over Veto: Every resolution and
motion, and every ordinance which is returned to the city council by the mayor,
shall be reconsidered by the city council at the next regular meeting following
the meeting at which the veto is actually or constructively received. (Ord. M-
57-79, 12-3-1979; Ord. M-11-03, 2-18-2003)
CHAPTER 7
CITY OFFICIALS
SECTION:
1-7-1: Elected And Appointed Officers
1-7-2: Term Of Office
1-7-3: Oath Of Office
1-7-4: Official Bonds
1-7-5: Official Salaries
1-7-6: Lawsuits Involving City Officers
1-7-7: Provisions Relating To City Officers
1-7-1: ELECTED AND APPOINTED OFFICERS:
   A.   Officers Of The City:
      1.   Elected: The mayor, aldermen and city clerk shall be elected in
accordance with the provisions of the Illinois municipal code.
      2.   Appointed: All other officers provided for by the provisions of this
code shall be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of the city council,
unless otherwise provided for in the provision creating such office 1
. (Ord. M-18-81, 4-6-1981; amd. Ord. M-60-84, 1-8-1984)
   B.   Certificate Of Election Or Appointment: The mayor shall issue a
certificate of election or appointment, under the seal of the city, to the city
clerk who shall immediately notify the person elected or appointed, using the
proper form as provided by statute. Any officer of the city shall, within five
(5) days after notification and request, deliver to his successor in office or
to the city clerk all property, books and effects of every description in his
possession belonging to the city or appertaining to his office. Upon his
refusal to do so, he shall be liable for all damages caused thereby and also be
subject to a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this title; and no financial settlement between the officer and the
city shall be made until the provisions of this section are fully complied
with. (1956 Code ch. 5 art. I; amd. 2002 Code)
   C.   Qualifications: No person shall be eligible for an elected office
unless he is a qualified elector of the city and unless he has resided therein
at least one year next preceding his election. No appointed officer shall be
required to be a qualified elector of the city nor shall any appointed officer
be required to be a resident of the city. No person shall be eligible for an
appointed or elected office who is a defaulter to the city. (Ord. M-17-74, 4-1-
1974)
   D.   Commission Of Officers: All officers elected or appointed shall be duly
commissioned by warrant under the city's seal, signed by the mayor and the city
clerk. (1956 Code ch. 5 art. I)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-5.
1-7-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
All officers appointed shall hold their offices during the calendar year in
which they are appointed and until their successors are appointed and
qualified, unless otherwise specifically provided by law or direction of the
city council at the time of such appointment. Effective upon the passage and
certification of the referendum on April 4, 2023, the number of terms of office
of each elected city official is limited to no more than two four-year terms of
office, whether consecutive or not. (Ord. M-67-03, 10-6-2003, eff. retroactive
to 11-3-1998; amd. Ord. M-84-23, 5-1-2023)
1-7-3: OATH OF OFFICE:
All officers of the city, elected or appointed, shall take and subscribe the
following oath or affirmation before entering upon the duties of their
respective offices:
   I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the constitution of the
United States and the constitution of the state of Illinois and that I will
faithfully discharge the duties of the office of             according to the
best of my ability.
This oath or affirmation shall be filed in the city clerk's office. (1956 Code
ch. 5 art. I; amd. 1963 Code)
1-7-4: OFFICIAL BONDS:
   A.   Bonds Required: The following officers of the city shall be required to
give bonds in the following amounts:
 
Mayor                                           Not less than $3,000.00
City clerk                                      Not less than $5,000.00
Director of finance and administrative services Statutory limit 1
 
All other officers, except aldermen, shall give bond in such sums as the mayor
and city council may by resolution require at the time of their election or
appointment, or as may be required by law. (Ch. 5 Art. III, 1956 Code; amd.
1963 Code; 2002 Code)
   B.   Condition Of Bonds: The bond of each officer shall be executed and made
payable to the city and shall be a surety company bond satisfactory to and
approved by the city council. The bond shall be conditioned for the faithful
performance of the duties of his office and the payment to the proper officer
all monies coming into his hands by virtue of his office.
   C.   Filing Of Bonds: After approval as aforesaid, the city clerk shall
endorse on each bond the date thereof and file the same in his office, except
the bond of the city clerk which shall be filed with the director of finance
and administrative services.
   D.   Failure To Qualify: If any person elected or appointed to any city
office shall fail to meet the bonding requirements aforesaid before the date he
is required to enter upon the duties of his office, the office shall become
vacant. (Ch. 5 Art. III, 1956 Code; amd. 1963 Code)
   E.   Officer Not To Be Surety For Another Officer: No officer of the city
shall furnish or become surety on the official bond of any other city officer,
under a penalty as provided in the general penalty in section
1-4-1 of this title. (Ch. 5 Art. I, 1956 Code; amd. 2002 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/5-3-9.
1-7-5: OFFICIAL SALARIES:
   A.   Mayor, Aldermen: Until the swearing in of elected officials following
the 2029 consolidated elections, the official salaries of the mayor and
aldermen are as follows:
 
Mayor    $9,600.00 per year
Aldermen $250.00 per month or a maximum per year of $3,000.00
 
      Upon the swearing in of elected officials following the 2029 consolidated
elections, the official salaries of the mayor and alderman will be as follows:
 
Mayor    $30,000.00 per year
Alderman $1,250.00 per month or a maximum per year of $15,000.00
 
      The salaries of the mayor and alderman that take effect following the
2029 consolidated elections will increase on an annual basis thereafter at a
rate of two percent per year. Effective June 5, 1989 and only until the
swearing in of elected officials following the 2029 consolidated elections,
aldermen shall also receive, not as compensation but as expenses, the sum of
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month representing expenses incurred as
a result of performing aldermanic duties. Effective July 1995 and only until
the swearing in of elected officials following the 2029 consolidated elections,
the mayor shall receive, not as compensation but as expenses, the sum of two
hundred dollars ($200.00) per month representing expenses incurred as a result
of performing mayoral duties.
 
   B.   City Clerk: Until the swearing in of elected officials following the
2029 consolidated elections, the official salary of the city clerk is as
follows:
 
Per year $6,000.00
 
      Upon the swearing in of elected officials following the 2029 consolidated
elections, the officials salary of the city clerk will be as follows:
 
Per year $12,000.00
 
      The salary of the City Clerk that takes effect following the 2029
consolidated elections will increase on an annual basis thereafter at a rate of
two percent per year.
   C.   Officers, Elected Officials:
      1.   All officers of the city shall receive such salaries, fees or
compensation as may be affixed by the city council, with minimum as established
by statute, if applicable. After such compensation has been fixed, it shall not
be increased or diminished so as to have any change take effect during the term
of which any officer affected by it was elected or appointed 1.
      2.   All salaries of elected officials shall be set as provided by state
law. (Ord. M-40-08, 11-3-2008)
   D.   Additional Compensation: The mayor and aldermen and city clerk shall,
during their respective terms of office, be eligible to participate, along with
their families, in the health, dental, and life insurance programs offered to
all city employees. For any such participant, the city will pay premiums for
the applicable health, dental, and life insurance program consistent with the
payments made by the city on behalf of city employees for such program, and any
such participant shall be required to pay premium costs, deductibles, copays,
coinsurance, and charges in excess of applicable coverage limitations that are
in effect from time to time during the term of their participation in the
programs as provided to all city employees. (Ord. M-9-16, 3-21-2016; amd. Ord.
M-10-25, 4-21-2025)
1-7-6: LAWSUITS INVOLVING CITY OFFICERS:
All lawsuits filed against elected or appointed city officials, in their
capacity as employees or agents of the city, shall be defended by the city. Any
judgments or expenses resulting therefrom shall be paid by the city unless a
determination or finding is made by the city council that the elected or
appointed official acted outside the scope of his position. (Ord. M-4-86, 1-20-
1986)
1-7-7: PROVISIONS RELATING TO CITY OFFICERS:
   A.   Holding Other Offices Prohibited: The mayor, aldermen and city clerk
shall hold no other office under the city government during his term of office,
unless hereinafter otherwise provided by law.
   B.   Inspection Of Records: All books, papers, vouchers, warrants,
correspondence, entries, accounts and memoranda of each and every officer
having any reference to city matters may be examined at any time by the mayor
or any member of the city council or any person whom the city council may
appoint to that purpose. The city council may, by resolution, call upon any
officer to make a report in writing concerning any subject matter pertaining to
his office, and within such time as the city council may designate in the
resolution.
   C.   Interest In Contracts: No officer of the city shall be directly or
indirectly interested in any contract, work or business of the city, or the
sale of any article, the expense, price or consideration of which is paid from
the treasury or by any assessment levied by any act or ordinance; nor in the
purchase of any real estate or other property belonging to the city, or which
shall be sold for taxes or assessments or by virtue of legal process at the
suit of the city.
   D.   Assignment Of Additional Duties: Besides the specific duties required
by law or the provisions of this code, every officer shall also perform such
other duties as usually pertain to his office. The mayor or the city council
may require or establish by ordinance any additional appropriate duties, rules
and regulations for the office.
   E.   Reports Of Monies Collected: Any officer of the city in any way charged
with the collection or handling of city monies shall, on the first day of each
month or more often if required, except where otherwise provided by law, turn
over to the director of finance and administrative services all such city
monies. Anyone who shall fail to account for same when so required, or who
shall default in the payment of any monies to the city as aforesaid, shall be
subject to immediate removal from office by the mayor and the city council.
(1956 Code ch. 5 art. I)
   F.   Badges 1
: Full time and volunteer members of the police department and fire department
shall be furnished with badges (stars) displaying the suitable emblem of
authority in their respective departments, and city officials shall be issued
suitable identification cards and badges. All badges shall be furnished at the
expense of the city. (Ord. M-89-01, 12-3-2001)
 
Notes
  1. See also section
1 3-2-9 and subsection
  3-3-5A of this code.
ARTICLE A. CITY MANAGER
SECTION:
1-7A-1: Office Created
1-7A-2: Appointment And Term
1-7A-3: Bond
1-7A-4: Powers And Duties
1-7A-5: Chain Of Command
1-7A-1: OFFICE CREATED:
There is hereby created the office of city manager, an administrative office of
the city. The city manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the
city. (Ord. M-14-88, 4-18-1988)
1-7A-2: APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
   A.   Appointment: The city manager shall be appointed by the mayor by and
with the advice and consent of the city council. The city manager shall be
chosen by the mayor and said choice shall be considered by the city council
solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications, with
special reference to actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practices in
respect to the duties of the office hereinafter set forth and such requirements
and qualifications are hereby declared to be of a nature as to require special
training, education and/or knowledge. No alderman or mayor shall receive such
appointment during the term for which he shall have been elected, nor within
one year after the expiration of that term. The city manager shall hold no
public elected office during his tenure as city manager. During the absence or
disability of the city manager, the mayor, with the advice and consent of the
city council, may designate some properly qualified person to act as city
manager pro tempore to perform the duties of the office. Upon the occurrence of
a vacancy, the mayor shall direct the human resources department to advertise
within fourteen (14) days of the vacancy, to fill the vacant city manager
position. (Ord. M-14-88, 4-18-1988)
   B.   Term Of Office: The term of office of the city manager shall be as
established through an employment contract. (Ord. M-17-92, 6-1-1992; amd. 2002
Code)
1-7A-3: BOND:
The city manager shall furnish a bond to the city conditioned for the faithful
performance of his duties and according to the provisions of section
1-7-4 of this chapter. (Ord. M-14-88, 4-18-1988)
1-7A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The city manager shall perform such duties as herein provided:
   A.   Chief Administrative Officer: As the chief administrative officer of
the city, the city manager shall be responsible to the mayor and to the city
council for the management and operation of all of the affairs and the
departments of the city, and shall have the management and control of all
matters and things pertaining to the operation and maintenance of the
properties of the city and of all of the departments of the city. The city
manager shall also have supervision of such other administrative agencies and
departments and officers as may be hereafter created by the city council unless
the management and control of such departments and officers is expressly
delegated elsewhere. The city manager shall have access and control of all
documents, including debts, mortgages, leases, contracts, judgment orders,
notes and bonds such as are directed by law or ordinance to be deposited
elsewhere. (Ord. M-27-89, 7-17-1989; amd. Ord. M-23-91, 6-17-1991; 2002 Code)
   B.   General Duties: Specifically, but not in limitation of the above, the
city manager shall have the following additional powers and duties:
      1.   Recommend to the mayor the appointment of all officers and employees
who are required by law to be appointed by the mayor. The city manager shall
recommend removal or suspension of any such officer or employee to the mayor
and city council, when such removal or suspension shall be consistent with the
best interests of the city. All such recommendations for appointment or any
removal or suspension shall be based upon merit and upon the qualifications or
disqualifications of such employee without regard to political belief or
affiliation. (Ord. M-17-92, 6-1-1992)
      2.   Have the power to appoint and to discharge any assistant city
manager, assistant to the city manager, administrative assistant to the city
manager or any executive secretary within the city manager's department. All
such appointments or discharges shall be based upon merit and the
qualifications or disqualifications of such employee. (Ord. M-14-99, 4-19-1999)
      3.   Have the power to recommend appointments and discharges of all civil
service employees, subject to rules and regulations of the civil service
commission, exclusive of employees and officers of the police department and
exclusive of regular firefighters employed on a full time basis, and as to said
excluded employees, the city manager shall abide by the provisions of the rules
and regulations of the police and fire commission. Upon discharge of any
employee, the city manager shall submit to the city council at the next meeting
following such removal a statement concerning said removal and the reasons
therefor.
      4.   From time to time recommend the consolidation, combination or
reorganization of job descriptions, departments or employment positions to the
mayor and city council. (Ord. M-14-88, 4-18-1988)
      5.   Prepare and submit to the city council a proposed annual budget for
the city. The total projected general fund balance in the proposed budget for
the end of the fiscal year shall not be less than ten percent (10%) of the
total budgeted expenditures for that fiscal year. (Ord. M-45-93, 9-20-1993)
      6.   Recommend to the mayor and the city council the salaries to be paid
each hired and appointed employee of the city. (Ord. M-14-88, 4-18-1988)
      7.   Make all necessary purchases of supplies and equipment for all
departments of the city. (Ord. M-14-88, 4-18-1988; amd. 2002 Code)
      8.   Attend all meetings of the city council unless excused therefrom by
the mayor, except when his removal is under consideration by the city council.
The city manager shall have the privilege of taking part in the discussion of
all matters coming before the city council. (Ord. M-14-88, 4-18-1988)
      9.   Make investigations into the affairs of the city or any department
or division thereof and shall investigate all complaints in relation to matters
concerning city services and city administration. (Ord. M-17-92, 6-1-1992)
      10.   Devote his entire time to the discharge of official duties.
      11.   Perform such other duties as may be required by the city council
consistent with the city ordinances and statutes of the state of Illinois.
(Ord. M-14-88, 4-18-1988)
1-7A-5: CHAIN OF COMMAND:
A majority of the city council shall instruct the city manager to convey their
policy and directives to the department heads and others on the staff. The city
manager has all the duties prescribed in the ordinance and the aldermen all
duties prescribed by state statute and the ordinances of the city. Aldermen
shall deal with the administrative service through the city manager, and
aldermen shall not give orders to any subordinates of the city manager, either
publicly or privately. (Ord. M-27-89, 7-17-1989)
ARTICLE B.CITY CLERK
SECTION:
1-7B-1: Qualifications And Duties
1-7B-2: Authority
1-7B-3: Principal Duties And Responsibilities
1-7B-1: QUALIFICATIONS:
The city clerk shall be a qualified elector of the city who shall have resided
within the city at least one (1) year next preceding the clerk’s election.
(Ord. M-15-19, 6- 3-2019; amd. Ord. M-5-25, 3-17-2025)
1-7B-2: AUTHORITY:
   A.   City Clerk: The city clerk shall work with the employees of the City
Clerk’s office to maintain and update the city's record keeping and to
undertake the other duties and responsibilities of the City Clerk as set forth
in this Article. Within limits of approved policies, procedures and programs,
the city clerk has authority to accomplish such duties in connection with the
keeping of public records as shall be ordained by state statutes, this code or
by direction of the city council. All employees of the City Clerk’s office
shall be under the supervision and control of the City Manager, or the
Manager’s designee.
   B.   Deputy City Clerk: The city clerk is authorized to appoint one deputy
clerk from city employees and the deputy clerk shall be empowered to affix the
deputy clerk’s authenticated signature to any and all necessary documents. Upon
such appointment, the city clerk shall report the same to the city council and
shall require the genuine signature of the deputy clerk to be inserted in the
journal of proceedings. In the absence of the city clerk, the deputy city clerk
is authorized to perform all duties of the city clerk to ensure continuity of
operations. (Ord. M-15- 19, 6-3-2019; amd. Ord. M-5-25, 3-17-2025)
1-7B-3: PRINCIPAL DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The city clerk shall have the following duties and functions:
   A.   Functions: The city clerk:
      1.   Shall be known as the secretary of the city council, and shall
handle all correspondence regarding city council activities.
      2.   Will work with the City Manager or the Manager’s designee on
processes and identifying efficiencies pertaining to the Clerk’s
responsibilities or duties, which may be delegated by the Clerk to the deputy
city clerk or other employees in the City Clerk’s office.
   B.   Meetings: The city clerk shall:
      1.   Attend all meetings of the city council and keep a full record of
its proceedings in the journal and prepare and distribute meeting minutes.
      2.   Issue notices of all regular, special and committee meetings of the
city council in compliance with the open meetings act requirements.
      3.   Prepare and publish annual calendar of meetings, post notices and
notifications to the press of all meetings of the city council, boards and
commissions.
   C.   Filing and Certification of Records and Documents: The city clerk
shall:
      1.   Keep all records of the city, including, but not limited to,
minutes, ordinances, resolutions, agreements, bonds, contracts, plats, deeds,
insurance policies, annexations, city owned property and maps, the custody and
control of which are not given to other officers. The city clerk shall be
responsible for the disposal of official records as allowed by law.
      2.   Be the official custodian of the city seal and certify documents
with the city seal, when applicable.
      3.   Obtain necessary signatures on City Council approved documents
related to Resolutions and Ordinances.
      4.   Prepare documents for recording, when applicable.
      5.   File applicable documents with county and state officials,
including, without limitation, tax levy, tax abatements, annexations and annual
treasurer's report, as required by law. Before filing, publish annual
treasurer's report in any newspaper of general circulation in the city, by June
30.
      6.   Responsible for the archiving of all city records as required.
      7.   Publish legal notices and all documents, which by law are required
to be published, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city.
      8.   Maintain and codify all codes and ordinances and provide for the
distribution of supplements.
      9.   Receive and distribute all communications addressed to the city
council or other city officials. The city clerk shall receive and distribute to
proper city officials all lawsuits served upon the city.   
   D.   Bidding Procedures: The city clerk shall:
      1.   Publish legal notice for bids.
      2.   Open all bids publicly at the designated time and place and in the
manner provided in the purchasing policy.
   E.   Elections: The city clerk shall:
      1.   Serve as the local election authority and perform such duties as set
forth by state statutes, the Cook County clerk and the city, including, without
limitation, register voters, process candidate petitions and local referendums.
      2.   Within five days after the result of any election is declared or
appointment is made, notify all persons elected or appointed.
      3.   Keep a record of the election or appointment of all officers
including Boards and Commissions of the city to include each officer's name,
office, the date of election or appointment, and date of death, resignation,
removal from office or expiration of term of office.
   F.   State and City Law Responsibilities: The city clerk shall:
      1.   Process all requests received under the freedom of information act.
      2.   Comply with state ethics legislation requirements, including,
without limitation, prepare list of city personnel required to file statement
of economic interest and certify the list to Cook County.
      3.   Comply with city ethics legislation requirements, maintain records
of ethics statements and other employment disclosure statements of all
applicable city officials (including, without limitation, the mayor, city
clerk, aldermen, department heads and any person acting as a department head,
along with appointed members of the planning and zoning board and the library
board). (Ord. M-15-19, 6-3-2019; amd. Ord. M-5-25, 3-17-2025)
CHAPTER 8
POSITION GRADE AND COMPENSATION PLAN
SECTION:
1-8-1: Grades
1-8-2: Application And Interpretation Of Position Grade And Compensation Plan
1-8-3: Administration And Maintenance Of The Position Grade And Compensation
Plan
1-8-4: Compensation Plan
1-8-5: Reserved
1-8-6: Administration And Maintenance Of Compensation Plan
1-8-1: GRADES:
   A.   Grades Of Positions: All nonunion full time positions, defined as
working 37.5 or more hours per week, in the City service shall be allocated to
grades, and each grade shall include those positions sufficiently similar in
respect to their duties and responsibilities so that similar requirements as to
training, experience, knowledge, skill, ability, and similar rates of
compensation are applicable thereto.
   B.   Classified Service: The classified service shall consist of those
nonunion positions in the grades set forth in the City's Personnel Policy
Manual. All union positions shall also be considered part of the classified
service and shall be as set forth in the applicable collective bargaining
agreements. Any changes to the classified service shall be made by amendments
to the City's Personnel Policy Manual, or pursuant to collective bargaining
agreements or amendments thereto.
   C.   Unclassified Service: The unclassified service shall consist of the
following positions, with such changes as may be approved by the City Council
by amendments to this chapter:
      Officers of the City elected by the people, including specifically:
      Mayor
      City Clerk
      Aldermen
   D.   Adoption Of Grade And Compensation Plan: The grades of classified
nonunion positions as set forth in Appendix U of the City's Personnel Policy
Manual, and the salary schedules for the associated positions. (Ord. M-11-19,
4-15-2019)
1-8-2: APPLICATION AND INTERPRETATION OF POSITION GRADE AND COMPENSATION PLAN:
Position descriptions for all positions shall be prepared by the Director of
Human Resources and shall be approved by the City Manager. These position
descriptions shall define the duties, responsibilities, and qualification
requirements of all positions. Each position description for nonunion positions
shall identify in which grade the position falls. (Ord. M-11-19, 4-15-2019)
1-8-3: ADMINISTRATION AND MAINTENANCE OF THE POSITION GRADE AND COMPENSATION
PLAN:
Responsibility: The Human Resources Director, under the direction of the City
Manager, is responsible for the administration and maintenance of the position
grade and compensation plan. (Ord. M-11-19, 4-15-2019)
1-8-4: COMPENSATION PLAN:
The compensation plan with annual rates for all nonunion classified positions
shall be contained in the City's Personnel Policy Manual. (Ord. M-11-19, 4-15-
2019)
1-8-5: RESERVED:
(Ord. M-24-13, 10-21-2013)
1-8-6: ADMINISTRATION AND MAINTENANCE OF COMPENSATION PLAN:
   A.   The annual pay range (minimum and maximum) of each grade and longevity
pay shown in Appendix U of the Personnel Policy Manual, shall be changed only
by the City Council through the annual budget adoption or via a separate
Resolution.
   B.   The Director of Human Resources, under the direction of the City
Manager, shall be responsible for the administration and maintenance of the
compensation plan. Changes in the compensation plan shall be made so as to
maintain the differentials between the grades and to reflect general increases
and changes in prevailing rates of pay for comparable positions outside the
City service. (Ord. M-11-19, 4-15-2019)
CHAPTER 9
CODE OF ETHICS
SECTION:
1-9-1: Policy Statement
1-9-2: Applicability
1-9-3: Definitions
1-9-4: Responsibilities Of Public Office
1-9-5: Disclosure
1-9-6: Conflict Of Interest
1-9-7: Gifts And Favors
1-9-8: Abuse Of Position
1-9-9: Confidential Information
1-9-10: Enforcement And Penalties
1-9-11: City Of Des Plaines Employment
1-9-12: Political Activities
1-9-13: Representation Before City Bodies Or Courts
1-9-14: Postcity Employment Restrictions
1-9-15: Validity Of Contract
1-9-16: Invalid Actions
1-9-17: Other Remedies
1-9-18:    Sexual Harassment Training, Reporting And Investigation
1-9-1: POLICY STATEMENT:
   A.   It is the policy of the city that, in all cases, its city officials and
employees perform their duties for the benefit of the citizens of the city.
They shall conduct the government of the city with integrity and impartiality,
without allowing prejudice, favoritism or the opportunity for personal gain to
influence their decisions or actions or to interfere with serving the public
interest.
   B.   The purpose of this chapter is to establish ethical standards of
conduct for all "city officials" as defined in section
1-9-3 of this chapter, by setting forth those acts or actions that are
incompatible with the best interests of the citizens of the city and by
directing disclosure by all city officials of private financial or other
