nonprobationary, noncivilian members of the department, and such election shall
be for the balance of the unexpired term. Any person elected to fill a board
position vacancy shall assume office immediately upon completion of the
election. (Ord. M-6-96, 2-20-1996)
2-10-3: ELECTION PROCEDURE:
   A.   Temporary Election Procedure: The Des Plaines firefighters association
shall establish a seven (7) member committee which shall be filled by
individuals selected from membership in the association. These individuals
shall adopt a procedure for the creation of the permanent board within the
meaning of the ordinance codified herein and the applicable state statute. The
temporary committee shall be responsible for organizing, conducting and
supervising the initial election of department members to serve on the Des
Plaines fire insurance tax board.
   B.   Permanent Election Procedure:
      1.   The board shall develop a procedure for governing the nomination of
members to run for the various offices to serve on the board. The nominating
procedure shall be established a minimum of thirty (30) days prior to the
expiration of the board members' terms of office.
      2.   The board shall develop a procedure for the final election of
members to the various offices on the board. The final election procedure shall
be established a minimum of thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the
board members' terms of office.
      3.   The board may adopt rules and regulations governing the election of
officers of the board. All rules and regulations with respect to the election
process shall be posted throughout the department a minimum of thirty (30) days
prior to the election. (Ord. M-6-96, 2-20-1996)
2-10-4: POWERS, DUTIES AND PROCEDURES:
   A.   The board shall make all needful rules and regulations with respect to
the Des Plaines foreign fire insurance tax board and/or the management of
monies appropriated to the board.
   B.   The board shall develop and maintain a listing of those items that the
board feels are appropriate expenditures under the state statutes.
   C.   All expenditures by the board shall be in accordance with all city
ordinances, concerning the expenditure of monies. Good and sound accounting
principals shall be followed regarding the holding and spending of any monies.
   D.   The funds of the board shall be annually reviewed as part of the city
audit. The audit shall verify that purchases by the board are for the
maintenance, use and benefit of the fire department.
   E.   The treasurer of the board shall give a sufficient bond to the city.
This bond shall be approved by the director of finance and administrative
services. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance by the
treasurer or his duties under the state statutes, ordinance, and the rules and
regulations adopted by the board.
   F.   The funds received by the city pursuant to the levy of the foreign fire
insurance company tax shall be set apart and shall be appropriated annually by
the city council to the Des Plaines fire department foreign fire insurance tax
board.
   G.   The treasurer of the board shall receive funds appropriated by the city
and shall pay out money and/or otherwise make expenditures upon the order of
the board. Any expenditures made by the treasurer, pursuant to the order of the
board shall be solely for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire
department.
   H.   The board shall establish a list of items and/or services from which it
shall select items and/or services to be purchased for the maintenance, use and
benefit of the fire department. The list shall be updated from time to time as
the board shall determine, but no less than annually on January 1 of each year.
The first such list shall be created or revised by April 1, 1996.
   I.   Prior to the purchase of any item(s) and/or service from the list which
the board intends to place within any fire station(s), the board shall submit a
written statement to the fire chief stating the descriptions of the items and/
or services and the proposed locations within any fire station(s). The fire
chief has the right to refuse to allow any such item(s) and/or service(s) into
any fire station(s). If the fire chief decides to allow any such item(s) and/or
service into any fire station, the fire chief shall also have the right to
refuse the board's proposed physical location of any such item(s) or rendering
of service in any fire station. The fire chief must respond in writing to any
written statement of the board within thirty (30) days from his receipt of same
and the fire chief must explain the basis for his decision(s). Upon the
purchase of any approved items, title to same shall be placed in the name of
the city.
   J.   The board may appeal any such decision rendered pursuant to subsection
I of this section to the city manager who shall render his decision in writing
within twenty one (21) days of his receipt of the fire chief's rejection. The
decision of the city manager may be appealed to the public safety committee of
the city council, by submission of a written request for review by the public
safety committee of the city manager's decision within twenty one (21) days of
the issuance of the city manager's decision. This written request for review
shall be submitted to the chair of the public safety committee. The public
safety committee shall consider the appeal as soon as is practicable. The
decision of the public safety committee shall be final. (Ord. M-6-96, 2-20-
1996)
2-10-5: QUORUM, SPECIAL MEETINGS:
The board shall, in accordance with the open meetings act, establish a regular
time and place for its meetings; and publish notice of same. The board shall be
subject to the provisions of the Illinois open meetings act. The chair shall
preside at board meetings, the secretary shall keep record of the proceedings
and actions of the board and may certify the same. Four (4) members of the
board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The chair may
call a special meeting at any time. A special meeting may also be called upon
the written notice of three (3) members of the board. Such notice shall be in
writing, duly signed by the board members. Such notice shall describe in brief
the nature or object of the special meeting. Any person shall be entitled to
appear and be heard on any matter before the board. Minutes of board meetings
shall be filed with the city clerk. (Ord. M-6-96, 2-20-1996)
CHAPTER 11
CONSUMER PROTECTION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-11-1: Established
2-11-2: Chair And Other Officers
2-11-3: Removal
2-11-4: Meetings And Rules Of Procedure
2-11-5: Compensation; Expenses
2-11-6: Definitions
2-11-7: Prohibited Acts And Practices
2-11-8: Exclusions
2-11-9: Powers Of The Commission
2-11-10: Procedures And Hearings
2-11-11: Penalties
2-11-1: ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a consumer protection commission for the city. Said
commission shall consist of seven (7) members, to be appointed by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council, four (4) of whom shall
constitute a quorum. They shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years, or
until their successors are appointed and qualified, except that the initially
appointed commission shall consist of one member who shall serve for one year,
two (2) members who shall serve for two (2) years, two (2) members who shall
serve for three (3) years and two (2) members who shall serve for four (4)
years. The membership shall, to the best extent possible, reflect a cross
section of consumer and business interests. At least two (2) members shall,
when possible, be representative of business. At least one member shall, when
possible, be a representative of a local community organization. (Ord. M-100-
07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-2: CHAIR AND OTHER OFFICERS:
   A.   By vote of the membership, one commission member shall be elected
annually from the commission membership to act as chair of the commission.
   B.   The commission may elect from its members a secretary and such other
officers as it may deem advisable. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-3: REMOVAL:
The mayor may, at his discretion, remove any commissioner for incompetence,
neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. The mayor shall, within ten (10)
days, report in writing any such removal to the city council, with the reasons
therefor. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-4: MEETINGS AND RULES OF PROCEDURE:
   A.   All fact finding meetings of the commission shall be held at the call
of the chair and at such times as the commission may determine.
   B.   The commission shall keep minutes of its meetings which shall be
available to the mayor and city council.
   C.   The facilities of the civic center shall be available to the commission
for all meetings.
   D.   The commission may adopt rules of order and procedure for the conduct
of its business.
   E.   All hearings conducted by the commission shall be open to the public.
Any person may appear, testify, make statements or present documents at a fact
finding hearing. The chair, or in his absence the acting chair, may administer
oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena. Attorneys may appear
with their clients. Attorneys shall not participate in the fact finding
process, but shall be limited to advising their clients regarding their
participation in the hearing. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-5: COMPENSATION; EXPENSES:
The members of the commission shall serve without compensation. Expenses for
the operation and conduct of the affairs of the commission shall be paid from
the budget of the city. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-6: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this chapter:
CONSUMER: An actual or prospective purchaser or lessee of property or an actual
or prospective purchaser of services in any "consumer transaction" as defined
in this section. A consumer shall also include a codebtor or surety on an
obligation of a consumer resulting from a consumer transaction, and a person to
whom an act or practice prohibited by this chapter is directed, although he is
not involved in a specific transaction.
CONSUMER TRANSACTION: Any sale or lease of property, or any contract for
services, primarily for a personal, household or family purpose, or a purchase
money security interest.
MERCHANDISE: Any property, personal or real, including, but not limited to,
goods, parts, materials and real estate.
PERSON: An individual, proprietor, partnership, corporation, firm, cooperative,
association or any other group of individuals or their agents, however
organized.
PURCHASE: Taking by sale, discount, negotiation, mortgage, lien or lease.
PURCHASE MONEY SECURITY INTEREST: A security interest that: a) is taken or
retained by the seller of the collateral to secure all or part of its price; or
b) is taken by a person who, by making advances or incurring an obligation,
gives value to enable the debtor to acquire rights in or the use of collateral
if such value is in fact so used.
SALE: Any sale, rental or distribution, offer for sale, rental or distribution
or attempt, directly or indirectly, to sell, rent or distribute.
SELLER: Any person who offers or makes available to consumers, either directly
or indirectly, merchandise, goods, services, credit or housing.
SERVICES: Work, labor or any other kind of activity furnished or agreed to be
furnished to a consumer, including, but not limited to, building and
construction services, underwriting services, the repair of automobile,
television sets and other similar commodities, the repair or installment of
plumbing, heating, electrical or mechanical devices, but not including those
services exempted by section
2-11-8 of this chapter. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-7: PROHIBITED ACTS AND PRACTICES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in a deceptive trade
practice whether or not any consumer has, in fact, been misled, deceived or
damaged thereby. Deceptive trade practices are:
      1.   Representations that goods or services have sponsorship, approval,
accessories, characteristics, ingredients, uses, benefits or quantities that
they do not have;
      2.   Representations that the merchant has a sponsorship, approval,
status, affiliation or connection that he does not have;
      3.   Representations that goods are original or new if they are
deteriorated, altered, reconditioned, reclaimed or secondhand;
      4.   Representations that goods or services are of particular standard,
quality, grade, style or model, if they are of another;
      5.   The misrepresentation as to a material fact which has a tendency to
mislead;
      6.   The failure to state a material fact if such use or failure deceives
or tends to deceive;
      7.   Disparaging the goods, services or business of another by false or
misleading representations of material facts;
      8.   Advertising or offering goods or services without intent to sell
them or sell them as advertised or offered;
      9.   Advertising or offering goods or services with intent not to supply
reasonably expected public demand, unless the advertisement or offer discloses
a limitation or quantity or other qualifying condition which does not have a
tendency to mislead;
      10.   Making false or misleading representations of fact concerning: the
reasons for, existence of or amounts of price reductions; or the price in
comparison to price of competitor's or one's own price at a past or future
time;
      11.   Knowingly making false statements that services, replacements or
repairs are needed;
      12.   Falsely stating the reasons for offering or supplying goods or
services at sale or discount prices;
      13.   The harassment of or threat to any person either by telephone,
cards or letters with regard to any act other than legal process;
      14.   Any deception, fraud, false pretense, false premise,
misrepresentation or the knowing concealment, suppression or omission of any
material fact with the intent that consumers rely upon such concealment,
suppression or omission in connection with the sale or advertisement of any
merchandise or with the subsequent performance of person aforesaid, whether or
not any person has, in fact, been misled, deceived or damaged thereby;
      15.   Any false, falsely disparaging or misleading oral or written
statement, visual description or other representation of any kind which has the
capacity, tendency or effect of deceiving or misleading consumers and is made
in connection with the sale, lease, rental, loan or bailment of consumer goods
or services; the offering for sale, lease, rental, loan or bailment of consumer
goods or services; the extension of consumer credit; or the collection of
consumer debts.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in an unconscionable
trade practice. Unconscionable trade practices are:
      1.   Failure to provide a written estimate of repairs, alterations,
modifications or servicing when requested by a consumer and the subsequent
repair, alteration, modification or servicing of any item without first
tendering said estimate;
      2.   Making repairs, alterations, modifications or service in exceeding
by twenty five percent (25%) or more the price quoted in a written estimate
without prior approval of a consumer;
      3.   Failure to reassemble or restore an electrical or mechanical
apparatus, appliance, chattel or other goods or merchandise to its tendered
condition unless a service or labor charge is paid, without notification prior
to receiving the tendered item of said service or labor charge;
      4.   Failure to supply to a consumer a copy of a sales or service
contract, lease, promissory note, trust agreement or other evidence of
indebtedness which that person may execute;
      5.   Making or enforcing unconscionable terms or provisions of sales or
leases. In applying this subsection, consideration shall be given to any of the
following factors:
         a.   Knowledge by the merchant at the time credit sales are
consummated that there was no reasonable probability of payment in full of the
obligation by the consumer.
         b.   Knowledge by the merchant at the time of the sale or lease of the
inability of the consumer to receive substantial benefits from the property or
services sold or leased.
         c.   Gross disparity between the price of the property or services
sold or leased and the value of the property or services measured by the price
at which similar property or services are readily obtainable in transactions by
like buyers or lessees.
         d.   The fact that the merchant contracted for or received separate
charges for insurance with respect to credit sales with the effect of making
the sales, considered as a whole, unconscionable.
         e.   The fact that the merchant has knowingly taken advantage of the
inability of the consumer reasonably to protect his interests by reason of
physical or mental infirmities, ignorance, illiteracy or inability to
understand the language of the agreement, or similar factors;
      6.   Replacing parts or components in an electrical or mechanical
apparatus, appliance, chattel or other goods or merchandise when such parts or
components are not defective unless requested by the consumer;
      7.   Falsely stating or representing that repairs, alterations,
modifications or servicing have been made and receiving remuneration therefor
when they have not been made. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-8: EXCLUSIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to:
   A.   Professional services of certified public accountants, architects,
clergymen, professional engineers, lawyers, veterinarians, insurance agents and
brokers licensed by the state, Christian Science practitioners, land surveyors
and property line surveyors, optometrists, physical therapists, podiatrists,
real estate brokers and salesmen and medical and dental practitioners engaging
in their respective professional endeavors.
   B.   Any television or radio broadcasting station or any publisher or
printer of a newspaper, magazine, or other form of printed advertising who
broadcasts, publishes or prints an advertisement which violates this chapter,
except insofar as such station or publisher or printer engages in a deceptive
or unconscionable practice in the sale or offering for sale of its own goods or
services or has knowledge of the advertising being in violation of this
chapter.
   C.   Public utility companies subject to the jurisdiction of the Illinois
commerce commission. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-9: POWERS OF THE COMMISSION:
The commission shall have the following powers and authority:
   A.   To receive and investigate complaints and initiate its own
investigation of deceptive or unfair trade practices against consumers; to hold
fact finding hearings, request the attendance of witnesses by subpoena,
administer oaths, take the testimony of any person under oath and, in
conjunction therewith, request the production of any evidence relating to any
matter under investigation or in question by the commission. At any hearing, a
witness shall have the right to be advised by counsel present during such
hearing.
   B.   Direct the chairman, by majority vote of the commission, to issue an
administrative hearing citation for the violations specified by the commission.
   C.   To present the interest of consumers before administrative and
regulatory agencies and legislative bodies.
   D.   To assist, advise and cooperate with better business bureaus and local,
state, and federal agencies and officials to protect and promote the interest
of the consumer public.
   E.   To assist, develop and conduct programs of consumer education and
information through public hearings, meetings, publications or other materials
prepared for distribution to the consumer public.
   F.   To undertake activities to encourage local business and industry to
maintain high standards of honesty, fair business practices and public
responsibility to the production and sale of consumer goods and services and in
the extension of credit.
   G.   To exercise and perform such other functions and duties consistent with
the purposes or provisions of this chapter which may be deemed necessary or
appropriate to protect and promote the welfare of consumers.
   H.   The consumer protection commission may require by subpoena the
attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of documentary
evidence relating to cases properly brought before the consumer protection
commission. The consumer protection commission may authorize the preparation
and service of subpoenas signed by the chairperson which may be served by the
proper authorities of the city, or any person lawfully authorized to serve
subpoenas under the laws of the state. The attendance of witnesses and the
production of documentary evidence may be required at a designated place within
the municipal boundaries of the city. In case of disobedience to the subpoena,
the commission may petition the circuit court of Cook County for an order
requiring the attendance and testimony of witnesses or the production of
documentary evidence or both. The court, upon the filing of such a petition,
may order the person refusing to obey the subpoena to appear at a designated
place pursuant to any investigation or hearing, or to there produce documentary
evidence, if so ordered, or to give evidence relating to the subject matter of
that investigation or hearing. Any failure to obey such order of the circuit
court may be punished by that court as a civil and/or criminal contempt upon
itself. All powers granted under this subsection shall terminate upon the
termination of commission or by city council action.
   I.   The commission shall have the power to enter into settlement agreements
for and on behalf of the parties and to enforce the provisions thereof through
the administrative hearing program. Failure to abide by the provisions of the
settlement agreement shall be conclusively deemed to be a violation of the
conditions of licensing and subject the respondent to the automatic imposition
of a minimum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Continued failure to abide
with provisions of the settlement agreement and to remit the fines and costs to
the city shall be cause for the commission to recommend revocation or
suspension of the business license pursuant to the provisions of this code and
subsections
4-2-11C and F of this code.
   J.   Any licensee that does not cooperate with all of the commission's
inquiries and hearing procedures may be recommended to the mayor or the city
council for license suspension or revocation pursuant to subsection
4-2-11C or F of this code. Any fees, fine or penalty payable to the city
pursuant to the powers of the commission, as outlined hereinabove, shall be
considered an amount due to the city pursuant to the provisions of subsection
4-2-11F of this code. Any failure to pay such amount shall be deemed a
delinquency within the meaning of subsection
4-2-11F of this code empowering the mayor or city council to act thereon. (Ord.
M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-10: PROCEDURES AND HEARINGS:
   A.   Any person subjected to a deceptive trade practice or unconscionable
trade practice as set forth in section
2-11-7 of this chapter may file with the commission a complaint in writing
which shall state the name and address of the person alleged to have committed
the violation complained of and the particulars thereof.
   B.   Upon filing a complaint as set forth in this section, the commission
shall make such investigation as it deems appropriate to ascertain facts and
issues. If the commission shall determine that there are reasonable grounds to
believe a violation has occurred and is susceptible of conciliation, it shall
attempt to conciliate the matter by methods of initial conference and
persuasion with all interested parties and such representatives as the parties
may choose to assist them. Conciliation conferences shall be informal. The
commission may direct that employees of the city responsible for serving the
commission conduct the conciliation.
   C.   The terms of conciliation agreed to by the parties may be reduced to
writing and incorporated into consent agreement to be signed by the parties,
which agreement is for conciliation purposes only and does not constitute an
admission by any party that the law has been violated. Consent agreements shall
be signed on behalf of the commission by the chair of the commission.
   D.   It shall be a violation of this chapter to violate or fail to adhere to
any provision contained in a consent agreement. Any failure by the commission
to enforce violation of any provision of a consent agreement shall not
constitute a waiver of any right of the commission or provision of such
agreement.
   E.   The commission, or its authorized representative is authorized to seek
the cooperation of all departments and agencies of the city in connection with
any investigation under this chapter by the commission.
   F.   If the commission determines that the complaint lacks reasonable
grounds upon which to base a violation of this chapter, the commission shall so
inform the complainant and the commission may, at the commission's discretion
dismiss such complaint or order such further investigations as may be
necessary.
   G.   If the commission determines that one or more sections of this chapter
have been violated, and settlement attempts were unsuccessful, it may direct
the chairman to issue an administrative hearing citation to the party or
parties alleged to have violated this chapter. The citation shall be issued in
accordance with
title 1, chapter 16 of this code. All formal hearings shall be conducted in
accordance with
title 1, chapter 16 of this code. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
2-11-11: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall be found to have committed a violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter shall be liable for the payment to the city of a
civil penalty, recoverable in a civil action, in the sum as set forth in the
general penalty in section
1-4-1 of this code for each such violation. In addition, any such person shall
be subject to injunctive or other appropriate action or proceeding to correct
any violation of this chapter, and any court of competent jurisdiction may
issue restraining orders, temporary or permanent injunctions or other
appropriate forms of relief. In addition, if such person wilfully ignores an
order of the commission, such person shall be liable for the payment to the
city of the city's attorney fees and costs incurred in the enforcement of the
order of the commission so ignored. The city may petition a court of competent
jurisdiction for an appropriate judgment order requiring the payment of such
sums. (Ord. M-100-07, 1-22-2008)
CHAPTER 12
CABLE SERVICES COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. M-14-08, 4-21-2008)
CHAPTER 13
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-13-1: Creation Of Commission
2-13-2: Intent And Purpose
2-13-3: Commission Membership
2-13-4: Meetings, Quorum, Voting
2-13-5: Records And Reports
2-13-6: Powers Of The Commission
2-13-7: Pecuniary Interest Of Members
2-13-1: CREATION OF COMMISSION:
There is hereby created a body politic and corporate to be known as the
Economic Development Commission (commission). (Ord. M-18-17, 8-21-2017)
2-13-2: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
To provide for the purpose of encouraging industrial development, commercial
business, retail and other supporting services which will provide job
opportunities, broaden the tax base, and improve the quality of living in the
City. (Ord. M-18-17, 8-21-2017)
2-13-3: COMMISSION MEMBERSHIP:
   A.   The commission shall consist of nine (9) members appointed by the Mayor
with the approval of the City Council.
   B.   Members must be a resident of the City for a minimum of two (2) years
or own a Des Plaines business and/or be in senior management of a company
conducting business within the City for a minimum of two (2) years.
   C.   Terms of incumbent membership shall commence on the date of appointment
as follows:
Five (5) members, each to serve a two (2) year term; and
Four (4) members, each to serve a four (4) year term.
Thereafter, new appointments made upon the expiration of the term of any
member, shall be made for a term of four (4) years. Any appointment to fill a
vacancy shall be for the remaining portion of such member's term.
   D.   Members of the commission shall hold office until their successors are
appointed and may serve more than one successive term.
   E.   Whenever a vacancy on the commission shall occur as a result of
resignation, death or any other reason other than expiration of the term of a
member, the Mayor shall appoint a member to complete the term of vacancy.
   F.   Members of the commission shall receive no compensation for their
services.
   G.   Removal from the commission by the Mayor shall be for cause.
   H.   The commission shall elect one member to serve as Chair and one member
to serve as Vice Chair.
   I.   The Director of Community of Economic Development, or his/her designee,
will be the staff liaison to the commission. (Ord. M-18-17, 8-21-2017)
2-13-4: MEETINGS, QUORUM, VOTING:
Regular meetings of the commission shall be scheduled on a quarterly basis at a
date and time to be determined by the commission and announced in the City
calendar and other appropriate media. Special meetings may be called by the
Mayor, City Council, or Chair of the commission or a quorum of the commission.
Five (5) members shall constitute a quorum. The Chairman shall vote with other
members of the commission. (Ord. M-18-17, 8-21-2017)
2-13-5: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
The commission shall keep written records of its proceedings, which records
shall be open at all times to public inspection. An annual report shall be made
to the City Council to include activities and matters before the commission.
(Ord. M-18-17, 8-21-2017)
2-13-6: POWERS OF THE COMMISSION:
The commission may exercise the following powers under this chapter; provided,
however, that in no event shall the commission encumber City funds or incur
City debt:
   A.   Advising the City on the development and implementation of business
retention/expansion programs;
   B.   Advising the City on the implementation of a marketing program to
attract new business and industry;
   C.   To propose and to assist in the preparation of, designation of, or
plans for, economic development projects and to assist in the undertaking and
carrying out of projects for economic development;
   D.   Monitoring business activity and trends on the local, State, and
national level;
   E.   Establishing a focal point for businesses to approach and discuss
issues that affect them; and
   F.   Engage representatives from community and regional entities such as the
Des Plaines Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Greater O'Hare Airport
Regional Business Association, Main Township School District 207; Oakton
Community College, the Des Plaines Public Library District, the Des Plaines
Special Events Commission, and other entities as appropriate on matters for
economic development. (Ord. M-18-17, 8-21-2017)
2-13-7: PECUNIARY INTEREST OF MEMBERS:
   A.   Any member of the commission who owns or controls any interest direct
or indirect in any property included in any project before the City Council or
commission shall disclose the same in writing to the commission and such
disclosure shall be entered upon the minute book of the commission.
   B.   No member of the commission shall vote or act on any project in which
said member holds an interest. (Ord. M-18-17, 8-21-2017)
CHAPTER 14
YOUTH COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-14-1: Intent And Purpose
2-14-2: Creation And Membership
2-14-3: Organization
2-14-4: Powers And Duties
2-14-5: Meetings
2-14-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
To provide for an appointive advisory body which shall promote, organize and
implement youth events as well as promote opportunities for youth to develop
youth leadership skills. The Youth Commission encourages and empowers the youth
of Des Plaines by providing fun, safe, and creative activities for them and
their families while promoting a spirit of community within the City. (Ord. M-
11-18, 6-4-2018)
2-14-2: CREATION AND MEMBERSHIP:
The Youth Commission, shall consist of nine (9) members, each of whom shall be
citizens of the City. The members of the Youth Commission shall be appointed by
the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. In addition, the Mayor shall be
an ex officio member of the Youth Commission.
   A.   1.   By vote of the membership, one commission member shall be elected
annually from the commission membership to act as Chair of the commission.
      2.   Each member shall serve for a term of four (4) years, or until his/
her successor has been duly appointed and qualified. The terms shall be
staggered so that five (5) of the originally appointed members shall each serve
a two (2) year term and four (4) of the originally appointed members shall each
serve a four (4) year term. Thereafter all appointments made upon the
expiration of the term of any member shall be for a four (4) year term.
   B.   The Mayor shall have the power to remove any member of the Youth
Commission for cause.
   C.   Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member or Chair
whose seat has become vacant by appointment of the Mayor with the consent of
the City Council.
   D.   When a commission member has missed four (4) meetings in one calendar
year, or four (4) consecutive meetings, the Chair shall contact said member to
discuss if said member wishes to continue serving on the commission. The Chair
shall subsequently make a recommendation to the Mayor as to the advisability of
said member's continuance on the commission. (Ord. M-11-18, 6-4-2018)
2-14-3: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Members of the Youth Commission shall serve without compensation of any
kind.
   B.   Immediately upon the creation of the Youth Commission, the members of
the commission shall select from its membership a Chair, Vice Chair and a
Secretary.
      1.   The Chair shall run all regular and special meetings of the
commission.
      2.   The Vice Chair shall serve as Acting Chair whenever the Chair is
absent from the meeting.
      3.   The Secretary shall oversee and be responsible for the record of
proceedings and shall prepare the minutes of said commission. A copy of the
minutes shall be forwarded to the City Clerk for distribution and for the
official files of the City. (Ord. M-11-18, 6-4-2018)
2-14-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the Youth Commission to develop, promote and
coordinate a series of youth oriented programming and activities.
   B.   All activities organized by the Youth Commission shall be conducted
within the financial constraints placed upon the commission, as established by
the Mayor and City Council through passage of the annual budget for the City
and in accordance with this Code, including the purchasing policies and
procedures of the City.
   C.   The Youth Commission shall prepare a calendar of events for the City.
Said calendar shall be presented to the Mayor and City Council on a quarterly
basis.
   D.   The Youth Commission shall have the power and authority to solicit and/
or accept commitments of contributions and in-kind services or products in
furtherance of the promotion and/or staging of any youth related events or
educational programming. All funds and in-kind services will be directed to and
made payable to the City of Des Plaines as coordinated by the staff liaison.
   E.   All agreements and contracts must be reviewed and approved by the City
Manager or staff liaison.
   F.   The Youth Commission may collaborate with the Des Plaines school
districts, Des Plaines Park District, Des Plaines Library and other Des Plaines
organizations for the purpose of carrying out the mission of said commission.
   G.   The Youth Commission may organize community activities, seminars,
volunteer opportunities, training/workshops for the benefit of Des Plaines
youth. (Ord. M-11-18, 6-4-2018)
2-14-5: MEETINGS:
The Youth Commission shall meet on a regular basis, as established by the
commission. Special meetings of the commission may be called by the Chair of
said commission. All meetings shall be conducted in compliance with the Open
Meetings Act. (Ord. M-11-18, 6-4-2018)
CHAPTER 15
KEEP DES PLAINES BEAUTIFUL COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. M-15-08, 4-21-2008)
CHAPTER 16
SPECIAL EVENTS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-16-1: Intent And Purpose
2-16-2: Creation And Membership
2-16-3: Organization
2-16-4: Powers And Duties
2-16-5: Meetings
2-16-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
To provide for an appointive advisory body which shall promote, organize and
implement special events of civic, patriotic, educational and cultural nature
in the City of Des Plaines. (Ord. M-10-18, 6-4-2018)
2-16-2: CREATION AND MEMBERSHIP:
The Special Events Commission, shall consist of nine (9) members, each of whom
shall be citizens of the City. The members of the Special Events Commission
shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. In
addition, the Mayor shall be an ex officio member of the Special Events
Commission.
   A.   1.   By vote of the membership, one commission member shall be elected
annually from the commission membership to act as Chair of the commission.
      2.   Each member shall serve for a term of four (4) years, or until his/
her successor has been duly appointed and qualified. The terms of the members
shall be staggered so that five (5) of the originally appointed members shall
each serve a two (2) year term and four (4) of the originally appointed members
shall each serve a four (4) year term. Thereafter all appointments made upon
the expiration of the term of any member shall be for a four (4) year term.
   B.   The Mayor shall have the power to remove any member of the Special
Events Commission for cause.
   C.   Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member or Chair
whose seat has become vacant by appointment of the Mayor with the consent of
the City Council.
   D.   When a commission member has missed four (4) meetings in one calendar
year, or four (4) consecutive meetings, the Chair shall contact said member to
discuss if said member wishes to continue serving on the commission. The Chair
shall subsequently make a recommendation to the Mayor as to the advisability of
said member's continuance on the commission. (Ord. M-10-18, 6-4-2018)
2-16-3: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Members of the Special Events Commission shall serve without
compensation of any kind.
   B.   Immediately upon the creation of the Special Events Commission, the
members of the commission shall select from its membership a Chair, Vice Chair
and a Secretary.
      1.   The Chair shall run all regular and special meetings of the
commission.
      2.   The Vice Chair shall serve as Acting Chair whenever the Chair is
absent from the meeting.
      3.   The Secretary shall oversee and be responsible for the record of
proceedings and shall prepare the minutes of said commission. A copy of the
minutes shall be forwarded to the City Clerk for distribution and for the
official files of the City. (Ord. M-10-18, 6-4-2018)
2-16-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the Special Events Commission to develop,
promote and coordinate a series of community events for the enjoyment and
education of the residents of the City and visitors to the City.
   B.   All activities organized by the Special Events Commission shall be
conducted within the financial constraints placed upon the commission, as
established by the Mayor and City Council through passage of the annual budget
for the City and in accordance with this Code, including the purchasing
policies and procedures of the City.
   C.   The Special Events Commission shall prepare a calendar of events for
the City. Said calendar shall be presented to the Mayor and City Council on a
quarterly basis.
   D.   The Special Events Commission shall have the power and authority to
solicit and/or accept commitments of contributions and in-kind services or
products in furtherance of the promotion and/or staging of any special events.
All funds and in-kind services will be directed to and made payable to the City
of Des Plaines as coordinated by the staff liaison.
   E.   All agreements and contracts must be reviewed and approved by the City
Manager or staff liaison.
   F.   The Special Events Commission may collaborate with the Des Plaines
school districts, Des Plaines Park District, Des Plaines Library and other Des
Plaines organizations for the purpose of carrying out the mission of said
commission.
   G.   The Special Events Commission may organize community activities,
volunteer opportunities, and events for the benefit of Des Plaines residents
and visitors. (Ord. M-10-18, 6-4-2018)
2-16-5: MEETINGS:
The Special Events Commission shall meet on a regular basis, as established by
the commission. Special meetings of the commission may be called by the Chair
of said commission. All meetings shall be conducted in compliance with the Open
Meetings Act. (Ord. M-10-18, 6-4-2018)
TITLE 3
MUNICIPAL DEPARTMENTS
CHAPTER 1
CITY MANAGER'S OFFICE
SECTION:
3-1-1: Department Established
3-1-2: City Manager
3-1-3: City Attorney
3-1-4: Director Of Human Resources
3-1-5: Director Of Health And Human Services
3-1-6: Director Of Information Technology
3-1-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established the department of the city manager's office. The
department shall consist of the city manager and such other officers or
employees as may be provided for by the city council in its annual
appropriation ordinance and budget. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-1-2: CITY MANAGER:
   A.   Office Established And Appointment: There is hereby established the
office of the city manager as set forth in section 1-7A-1 of this code.
   B.   Powers And Duties: The powers and duties of the city manager are as set
forth in section 1-7A-4 of this code. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-1-3: CITY ATTORNEY:
   A.   Office Established And Appointment: There is hereby established the
office of the city attorney. The city attorney shall be licensed to practice
law in the state. The city attorney shall be appointed by the city manager.
Political considerations shall not be used in the selection or removal of the
city attorney.
   B.   Powers And Duties: The powers and duties of the city attorney shall
include, but are not limited to, the following:
      1.   The city attorney, under the direction of the city manager, shall be
the full time legal advisor to the city and shall advise the city council and
city manager or any department head or officer of the city on all legal matters
in which the interests of the city are involved, including rendering legal
opinions when requested and trying cases. The city attorney shall review all
ordinances and resolutions required by the city council and shall attend all
meetings of the city council, and other meetings when so directed by the city
manager. All records, papers, files and other documents and materials prepared
for the city or used by the city attorney while so employed by the city are the
sole property of the city. The city attorney shall be employed in no other
business, position or occupation whatsoever, or engage in the practice of law
other than for the city; provided, however, that with the consent of the city
manager, the city attorney may be permitted to engage in limited and temporary
outside work where the same does not interfere with the duties of the position.
      2.   The city attorney shall be the head of the legal division and shall
have supervision over all employees of the division and shall be responsible
for the performance of their duties.
      3.   Any attorney other than the city attorney handling a matter on
behalf of the city shall keep for each matter handled a record in which shall
be noted all steps taken in such matter. Upon the completion of such matter or
upon the termination of employment, the attorney shall forthwith turn over to
the city attorney such record and all papers or documents belonging to the city
or prepared in connection with the matter and a statement in writing giving
such information as may be available with respect to the matter.
      4.   All attorneys representing the city shall provide quarterly status
reports on all matters handled by them to the city attorney. The city attorney
shall make quarterly reports to the city council and city manager of all
actions being handled by all attorneys representing the city. Such status
reports shall contain an update of each case, potential dollar amount demanded,
the final settlement amount unless prohibited from disclosure by law, and the
attorney assigned to each case.
      5.   The city attorney shall have settlement authority from zero dollars
($0.00) to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). For claims that exceed five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00), but do not exceed ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00), the city attorney shall recommend settlement to the city manager,
who in turn, if in agreement, will authorize the city attorney to make
settlement in that range. For claims that exceed ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00), but do not exceed fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00), the city
attorney shall recommend settlement to the mayor and the city manager, who in
turn, if they are in agreement, will authorize the city attorney to make
settlement in that range. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-1-4: DIRECTOR OF HUMAN RESOURCES:
   A.   Office Established And Appointment: There is hereby established the
office of the director of human resources. The director of human resources
shall be appointed by the city manager. Political considerations shall not be
used in the selection or removal of the director of human resources.
   B.   Powers And Duties: The powers and duties of the director of human
resources shall include, but are not limited to, the following:
      1.   Advise and make recommendations to the city council and city manager
on matters of personnel organization and administration;
      2.   Maintain and keep current the position classification and
compensation plan;
      3.   Administer a recruitment and selection program for employment in the
city classified service;
      4.   Administer the maintenance of records of all city employees;
      5.   Administrate the following employee benefit programs: health and
life insurance plan, retirement, safety and workers' compensation and
unemployment insurance;
      6.   Assist with the preparation of salary and benefit cost projections
for the annual city budget as well as ensure required federal, state and
related reports are appropriately filed;
      7.   The director of human resources shall be the head of the human
resources division and shall have supervision over all employees of the
division and shall be responsible for the performance of their duties. (Ord. M-
26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-1-5: DIRECTOR OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES:
   A.   Office Established And Appointment: There is hereby established the
office of the director of health and human services. The director of health and
human services shall be appointed by the city manager. Political considerations
shall not be used in the selection or removal of the director of health and
human services.
   B.   Duties: The duties of the director of health and human services shall
include, but are not limited to, the following:
      1.   Administer social service programs, case management, community
education forums and act as general information and referral agency;
      2.   Administer programs of public health including education on disease
suppression and control, maternal and child health, school health and referral
to local community health programs and services;
      3.   The director of health and human services shall be the head of the
health and human services division and shall have supervision over all
employees of the division and shall be responsible for the performance of their
duties. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-1-6: DIRECTOR OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY:
   A.   Office Established And Appointment: There is hereby established the
office of the director of information technology. The director of information
technology shall be appointed by the city manager. Political considerations
shall not be used in the selection or removal of the director of information
technology.
   B.   Duties: The duties of the director of information technology shall
include, but are not limited to, the following:
      1.   Administer the citywide computer system, which consists of servers,
numerous personnel computers, and printers;
      2.   Support the telephone system, citywide financial system, e-mail,
word processing and spreadsheet software, and various other software programs
specific to city departments;
      3.   The director of information technology shall be the head of the
information technology division and shall have supervision over all employees
of the division and shall be responsible for the performance of their duties.
(Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
CHAPTER 2
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-2-1: Department Established
3-2-2: Chief Of Police
3-2-3: Deputy Chiefs Of Police And Police Commanders
3-2-4: Citizens To Aid Police
3-2-5: Police To Aid Other Governmental Entities
3-2-6: General Powers And Duties
3-2-7: Reports
3-2-8: Departmental Rules
3-2-9: Uniforms And Badges
3-2-10: Auxiliary Police Officers
3-2-11: Police Dogs
3-2-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a police department for the public protection of
the city. All sworn officers of the department shall be appointed in accordance
with the provisions of the fire and police commission regulations set forth in
title 2, chapter 6 of this code, except for the exempt positions of police
chief, deputy police chief, and police commander. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-2-2: CHIEF OF POLICE:
   A.   Office Established And Appointment: There is hereby established the
office of chief of police as the chief officer of the police department. The
police chief shall be appointed by the city manager. Political considerations
shall not be used by the city manager in the selection or removal of the chief
of police.
   B.   Powers And Duties: The police chief shall superintend the police force
of the city and shall have the custody, care and control of the public property
of the department, including all firearms and other equipment thereof, subject
to the orders of the city council and city manager. The police chief shall
devote his or her sole time to preserve the peace and order of the city and
shall execute and enforce all orders of the city council, board of fire and
police commissioners and the city manager, and shall be solely responsible for
the efficient operation of the department. The police chief shall formulate and
establish a set of administrative rules and regulations to govern the operation
of the department. These rules and regulations or any subsequent changes
thereto shall be approved by the city manager before becoming effective and
copies shall be prepared for distribution to all concerned or affected thereby.
The police chief shall see that all members of the department obey these rules
and regulations. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-2-3: DEPUTY CHIEFS OF POLICE AND POLICE COMMANDERS:
   A.   Deputy chiefs of police and police commanders shall be positions exempt
from the board of fire and police commissioners' jurisdiction. Deputy chiefs of
police and police commanders shall be hired by the police chief with the
concurrence of the city manager. Selection procedures for the exempt rank of
deputy chief of police and police commander are to be determined by the chief
of police.
   B.   The duties and assignments of the deputy chiefs of police and
commanders shall be as established and determined by the police chief. The
deputy chiefs of police and police commanders shall report to the police chief
or designee as assigned.
   C.   Political considerations shall not be used by the police chief in the
selection or removal of the deputy chiefs of police or police commanders.
   D.   The deputy chiefs of police and police commanders may be removed from
the position by the police chief, with the concurrence of the city manager,
without cause at any time, whereupon said individual would return to his or her
previous rank in the classified service of the police department. (Ord. M-26-
07, 5-5-2008)
3-2-4: CITIZENS TO AID POLICE:
It shall be the duty of any person in the city, eighteen (18) years of age or
older, when called upon by any member of the police department, in case of
emergency, to promptly aid and assist such police officer in the execution of
his police duties. Any person who shall refuse to give such aid and assistance
shall be fined as provided in the general penalty in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-2-5: POLICE TO AID OTHER GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES:
It shall be the duty of the police department to aid the fire department
clearing streets or grounds in the vicinity of the fire, so that members of the
fire department shall not be hindered or obstructed in the performance of their
duties. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-2-6: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Serving Process: The police chief and any police officer shall have
power and authority, and it shall be his or her duty in the city, to serve and
execute warrants and other process for the apprehension and commitment of
persons charged with the violation of any city law or any crime, misdemeanor or
offense against the peace of the state or the city, or held for examination or
trial, or taken on execution for the commission of any crime, misdemeanor or
violation of any law of the city, and while serving or executing, be vested
with and have all the powers and authority conferred upon police officers by
the common law and the laws of the state.
   B.   Arrests Authorized: The members of the police department are hereby
severally authorized to arrest, with or without process, or on view, any person
who shall break the peace or be found breaking the law of the city or any
criminal law of the state, and to take such person before the proper court, or
if necessary detain such person in custody in the city jail, or any other safe
place, until they can be brought before the proper court for trial.
   C.   Serve As Witnesses: All police officers making arrests shall attend as
witnesses before the court where the trial may be had, and shall procure all
necessary evidence in their power, and furnish a list of the witnesses to the
court and the attorney. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-2-7: REPORTS:
The chief of police shall prepare the following reports, not to include the
responsibility of individuals to report accidents:
   A.   Arrests: The chief of police shall keep a record in the police
department of the names of all persons arrested or committed to the city jail.
This record shall show the date of arrest or committal, the number of days in
jail, the amount of the fine, when and to whom paid, and the date of discharge
or other disposition of the person.
   B.   Annual Reports: The chief of police shall make an annual report in
writing to the city council and city manager of the state of the police
department, with a detailed statement of the transactions of the police
department for the preceding year, with such statistics and suggestions in
regard to the requirements and improvements of the department as he may deem
advisable; and shall also make reports of any matter or thing concerning the
department whenever requested by the mayor and city council. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-
5-2008)
3-2-8: DEPARTMENTAL RULES:
The members of the police department shall be subject to and perform their
duties under rules and regulations formulated and established by the chief and
approved by the city manager. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-2-9: UNIFORMS AND BADGES:
Every member of the police department shall wear a suitable badge 1
, to be furnished by the city, and every regular police officer shall wear a
suitable uniform to be furnished as provided by this code. Any member who shall
lose or destroy the badge or other property furnished to him by the city shall
be required to pay the cost of replacing it. Whenever any member shall leave
the department, the officer shall immediately deliver his badge and all other
articles in his possession belonging to the city to the chief of police, and no
bill for final settlement between the police officer and the city shall be paid
by the city until this last provision has been complied with. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-
5-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  1-7-7F of this code.
3-2-10: AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS:
   A.   Appointment: The mayor is hereby authorized to appoint auxiliary police
officers as employees, upon the recommendation of the chief of police and
certification by the city clerk. Prior to appointment, all proposed auxiliary
police officers shall be fingerprinted and their fingerprints shall be checked
with the federal bureau of investigation, Washington, D.C., for any possible
criminal record. No person shall be appointed as an auxiliary police officer if
he has been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude. The
appointment of any or all auxiliary police officers may be terminated by the
chief of police.
   B.   Requirements: Such auxiliary police officers shall not be members of
the regular police department of the city. Identification symbols worn by such
auxiliary police officers shall be different and distinct from those used by
the regular police department, and shall be selected and chosen by the chief of
police. Auxiliary police officers shall at all times during the performance of
their duties be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police.
   C.   Powers And Duties: Auxiliary police officers shall have the following
powers and duties, when properly assigned and on duty:
      1.   To aid or direct traffic in the municipality.
      2.   To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters.
      3.   To aid in case of civil disorder.
      4.   To perform normal and regular police duties when assigned by the
chief of police on occasions when it is impracticable for members of the
regular police department to perform normal and regular police duties.
   D.   Restriction: Auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms except
with the permission of the chief of police and then only when in uniform and in
the performance of their duties.
   E.   Training Required: Prior to entering upon any of their duties,
auxiliary police officers shall receive a course of training in the use of
weapons and other police procedures by the chief of police. Such course of
training shall not be less than that which is mandated by the Illinois Compiled
Statutes.
   F.   Remuneration: Auxiliary police officers shall receive no compensation
for services performed, except in specific instances when recommended by the
chief of police and approved by the city manager. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-2-11: POLICE DOGS:
   A.   Teasing, Striking Or Tampering With Police Dog: It shall be unlawful
for any person to intentionally or maliciously:
      1.   Taunt, torment, tease, beat, strike or otherwise harass any police
canine; or
      2.   Administer or subject any desensitizing drugs, chemicals or
substance to a police canine; or
      3.   Interfere or meddle with any police canine used by any law
enforcement officer in the performance of his functions or duties within the
city or when placed in a kennel off duty.
Any person found guilty of a violation of this subsection shall be subject to a
fine as provided in the general penalty in section
1-4-1 of this code for each and every offense.
   B.   Injuring Or Killing Police Dog: It shall be unlawful for any person to
intentionally or maliciously torture, mutilate, injure, disable, poison or kill
any police canine used by a law enforcement department or agency in the
performance of functions or duties within the city or when placed in a kennel
off duty. However, a police officer or veterinarian may perform euthanasia in
emergency situations when delay would cause undue suffering and pain.
Any person found guilty of a violation of this subsection shall be subject to a
fine not to exceed the cost of replacement and training of the new police
canine. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
CHAPTER 3
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
3-3-1: Department Established
3-3-2: Fire Chief
3-3-3: Fire Department Personnel
3-3-4: Apparatus And Equipment
3-3-5: General Provisions
3-3-6: Enforcement
3-3-7: Emergency Response Reimbursement
3-3-8: Fire And Ambulance Service
3-3-1: DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established the fire department for the prevention and
extinguishment of fire endangering life and property and provision of emergency
medical services within the limits of the city and beyond the city limits where
contractual fire protection agreements have been or may be made. The department
shall consist of the fire chief and such other employees as may be provided for
by the city council in its annual appropriation ordinance and budget. (Ord. M-
26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-3-2: FIRE CHIEF:
   A.   Office Established And Appointment: There is hereby established the
office of the fire chief. The fire chief shall be appointed by the city
manager. Political considerations shall not be used by the city manager in the
selection or removal of the fire chief.
   B.   Powers And Duties: The fire chief shall at all times have full control
and command over all members of the department, the fire apparatus and
equipment belonging to the city, and their usage in accomplishing the
objectives of the department. In addition, the fire chief shall be responsible
for the following activities:
      1.   Formulate and establish a set of administrative rules and
regulations to govern the operations of the department. These rules and
regulations or any subsequent changes thereto shall be approved by the city
manager before becoming effective and copies shall be prepared for distribution
to all concerned or affected thereby. The fire chief shall see that all members
of the department obey these rules and regulations.
      2.   Determine the response of fire apparatus and manpower to alarms and
shall attend those emergencies which in the fire chief's judgment require the
fire chief's presence.
      3.   Conduct suitable training and/or instructions for the members of the
department in fire suppression; emergency medical services; specialized rescue;
and fire prevention, inspection, investigation, and education, and all other
matters essential to good firemanship and the safety of life and property from
fire or other hazards. The fire chief may delegate the instruction to the
training division or other especially qualified instructors who have knowledge
and skills in particular subjects.
      4.   Keep or cause to be kept complete records of all fires, inspections,
investigations, apparatus and equipment, hose records, purchase and maintenance
costs of equipment, personnel, attendance at meetings and at fires, and all
other pertinent information about the department and its operation. A station
logbook, permanently bound, shall be kept at all fire stations by the watch
officer on duty there, showing the firefighters on duty on each shift, the
firefighters responding to alarms and drills, the firefighters out of the
station on inspection work, and all other fire station activity, all in
chronological order.
      5.   Submit a monthly report to the city manager containing information
on fire department operations, inspections, education, training, number and
types of emergency responses, and other pertinent information deemed necessary
to keep the city council up to date with fire department activities.
      6.   Render a complete annual report in writing to the city council and
city manager. Said report to include summaries of the information required in
the preceding subsections herein, together with the fire chief's
recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the department.
      7.   Consult with city officials and the police and fire commission at
all times so that the rules and regulations the fire chief may prescribe for
the governance of the department are not at variance with state law and the
rules of the commission.
      8.   Bring formal charges to the police and fire commission against any
member of the fire department for the incompetency, neglect of duty,
disobedience to orders, or flagrant violation of any rule and regulation of the
department, and pending a hearing before the commission of such charges, the
fire chief may suspend the member charged from duty until the commission can
make its investigation and adjudicate the charges.
      9.   Cause to be investigated the cause, origin and circumstances of all
fires within the department's jurisdiction. The fire chief shall immediately
report all suspicious fires to the police department for appropriate police
action.
      10.   Have authority to enter, or cause to be entered by subordinates any
and all buildings and premises for the purpose of making inspections or
investigating fires and their causes, and shall serve written notice on such
building owners or occupants of property to abate, within a specified
reasonable time, any and all fire hazards found and ordered abated.
      11.   Have the power to modify the provisions of any fire safety law when
there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter
of the law; provided, the spirit of the law is observed and the modification is
clearly stated in writing.
      12.   Execute such other duties and responsibilities as the city manager
may direct.
      13.   With the concurrence of the city manager, execute on behalf of the
city all indemnification, hold harmless and liability releases in favor of or
against the city and/or fire department in relation to any and all programs
involving the use of any and all structures, apparatus and equipment belonging
to the fire department and in relation to any and all training programs and/or
trainees. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-3-3: FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL:
   A.   Deputy fire chiefs, fire division/battalion chiefs, and training
division chief/safety officer shall be positions exempt from the board of fire
and police commissioners' jurisdiction. Deputy fire chiefs, fire division/
battalion chiefs, and training division chief/safety officer shall be hired by
the fire chief with the concurrence of the city manager. Selection procedures
for the exempt sworn ranks of deputy fire chief and fire division/battalion
chief, and for the exempt civilian position of training division chief/safety
officer are to be determined by the fire chief.
   B.   The duties and assignments of the deputy fire chiefs, fire division/
battalion chiefs, and training division chief/safety officer shall be as
established and determined by the fire chief. The deputy fire chief(s) shall
report to the fire chief. The fire division/battalion chiefs and training
division chief/safety officer shall report to the deputy fire chiefs as
assigned.
   C.   Political considerations shall not be used by the fire chief in the
selection or removal of the deputy fire chiefs, fire division/battalion chiefs,
and training division chief/safety officer.
   D.   The deputy fire chiefs, division/battalion chiefs, and training
division chief/safety officer may be removed from the position by the fire
chief, with the concurrence of the city manager, without cause at any time. In
such instance, a deputy fire chief or division/battalion chief would return to
his or her previous board of fire and police commissioners' rank in the fire
department. (Ord. M-38-11, 9-19-2011)
3-3-4: APPARATUS AND EQUIPMENT:
The city council shall determine with the advice and counsel of the fire chief,
the amount, type and size of all fire apparatus and equipment comprising the
fire department and shall purchase, repair or replace any and all fire
apparatus and equipment and accessories they deem necessary as provided by
state law. In addition:
   A.   The city council shall designate and provide safe and convenient
housing for all fire apparatus and equipment.
   B.   The city council shall establish suitable arrangements for notifying
all members of the department of alarms of fire, and it is incumbent upon
members to arrange for forwarding alarms to themselves when they are called
away from home or their place of business.
   C.   No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment of the city for any
private purpose; nor shall it be used by any other department of the city
without the express permission of the fire chief; nor shall any person wilfully
and without proper authority take away or conceal any article used in any way
by the fire department.
   D.   The mayor is hereby authorized, with the approval of the city council,
to enter into agreements with the contiguous fire protection districts,
properly formed under state law, and adjacent municipalities; provided, such
agreements shall specify that the officer in charge of the fire department
shall have the authority to refuse response to such calls if, in his or her
judgment, the absence of fire apparatus would unduly endanger the protection of
the city. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-3-5: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
The following general provisions shall apply to the operation of the fire
department:
   A.   Badge Of Office: The city shall furnish every member of the department
with a badge designating his or her rank in the department 1
.
   B.   Interference, Refuse To Aid: No person shall interfere with a
firefighter in the performance of his or her duty, nor shall they refuse or
neglect to furnish any member of the fire department any help or information
they may possess as to the cause or origin of any fire, or hinder any fire
investigation in any manner.
   C.   Fire Flow/Hydrant Test Fee: Any and all requests for hydrant tests and/
or fire flow tests, whether from an individual or outside agency, shall be made
to the fire prevention bureau and such tests shall be witnessed by the Des
Plaines fire department. Fees shall be charged for such tests as follows:
 
Telephone request for fire flow information or test results on file No charge
Request for a copy of fire flow test results of test information on $11.00
file
Fire flow/hydrant test conducted by individual/agency witnessed by  27.50
fire department
Fire flow/hydrant test conducted by individual agency using fire    55.00
department test equipment and witnessed by fire department
Fire flow/hydrant test conducted by fire department                 110.00
 
Prior to conducting any test and/or forwarding any test results, a check made
out to the city for the appropriate fees must be received by the fire
prevention bureau. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection
  1-7-7F of this code.
3-3-6: ENFORCEMENT:
Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the general penalty provided in
section
1-4-1 of this code. In addition:
   A.   All members of the fire department are hereby given the necessary
police powers for enforcing this chapter applying at the scene of an emergency
incident.
   B.   Any member of the department violating the rules and regulations of the
department or who is guilty of the charges brought against him or her before
the fire and police commissioners may be fined, suspended for a specified time
without pay, or discharged from the department as the commission shall
determine and direct. (Ord. M-26-07, 5-5-2008)
3-3-7: EMERGENCY RESPONSE REIMBURSEMENT:
   A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following words and
terms shall have the following meanings:
   CITY: Any department or division of the city of Des Plaines.
   COVERED EXPENSES: All costs and expenses incurred by the city and by any
mutual aid and automatic aid responders that are in any way related to a
hazardous materials incident response, including, without limitation, the
cleanup and abatement of hazardous materials, the extinguishing of any fire
involving hazardous materials, the provision of medical services, the
restoration of public and private property damaged by, or during the response
to, a hazardous materials incident, and any legal action in any way related to
or arising from a hazardous materials incident. Covered expenses include,
without limitation, actual labor costs, including, without limitation, workers'
compensation benefits, fringe benefits, administrative overhead, and attorney
fees; any medical expenses, immediate or long term, of personnel exposed to
hazardous materials; the cost of equipment operation, damage, or loss; the cost
of materials used or consumed during a response to a hazardous materials
incident; and the cost of any labor and materials furnished by any contractors
hired by the city to assist in a response to a hazardous materials incident.
   HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: Any substance or material which, due to its quantity,
form, concentration, location or other characteristics, is determined by the
chief of the city fire department, or his authorized representative, based upon
a reasonable degree of scientific certainty, to pose an unreasonable and
inordinate risk to the life, health, or safety of persons or property or to the
ecological balance of the environment. Hazardous materials include, without
limitation, explosives, compressed gases, asbestos, flammable and combustible
liquids, flammable and water reactive solids, oxidizers and peroxides, poisons,
radioactive materials, corrosives or other regulated materials, or any
substance determined to be hazardous or toxic under any federal or state law,
statute or regulation.
   HAZARDOUS MATERIALS INCIDENT: Any incident involving the spill, leak,
release, seepage, emission, ignition, or combustion of any hazardous material
on public or private property.
   RESPONSIBLE PARTY: Any person or entity who owns, possesses, or controls any
hazardous materials involved in a hazardous materials incident, or who in any
way caused, or contributed to the cause of, a hazardous materials incident.
Responsible parties include, without limitation, any persons or entities in
immediate control of hazardous materials involved in a hazardous materials
incident; the shipper, manufacturer, distributor, and transporter of hazardous
materials involved in a hazardous materials incident; and any other persons or
entities who caused or contributed to the cause of a hazardous materials
incident.
   B.   Hazardous Materials Incidents Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any
person, with or without fault, to release, emit, spill, or leak any hazardous
material on public or private property.
   C.   Reimbursement Of Covered Expenses: All responsible parties shall be
strictly liable and jointly and severally liable for all covered expenses in
any way related to any response by the city and any mutual aid or automatic aid
responders to a hazardous materials incident. Responsible parties shall
reimburse the city and any mutual aid or automatic aid responders for all
covered expenses not later than ten (10) days after receipt of notice thereof
from the city.
   D.   Use Of Reimbursement Funds: The reimbursement funds may be used by the
city and any mutual aid and automatic aid responders to offset any covered
expenses and to replace and replenish any supplies used to respond to a
hazardous materials incident. Such supplies may include, without limitation,
protective clothing, absorbants, neutralizing chemicals, detection and
monitoring equipment, firefighting foams and chemicals, and equipment and
supplies damaged or destroyed during the response to the hazardous materials
incident.
   E.   Remedies: In addition to any other remedies available to the city at
law or equity, the city may file a civil suit and obtain a judgment against any
responsible party who does not reimburse the city in accordance with the
provisions of this section. Nothing in this section shall be deemed to relieve
any party from any other obligations or responsibilities that it may have to
any other agency or party under any other law.
   F.   Penalty: In addition to any other applicable penalties, violations of
any provision of this section are punishable in accordance with section
1-4-1 of this code. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has
been served shall be deemed a separate offense. In addition to any covered
expenses, violators of any provision of this section must reimburse the city
for all costs and expenses, including, without limitation, attorney fees, court
costs, and administrative expenses, incurred by the city to enforce the
provisions of this section and to obtain a judgment for any amounts due and
owing to the city in accordance with the provisions of this section. (Ord. M-
14-14, 5-19-2014)
3-3-8: FIRE AND AMBULANCE SERVICE:
   A.   Service Outside City:
      1.   Applicability: This subsection A shall apply to all parcels of land
bordering the corporate limits of the city that are not protected by a fire
protection district or another municipal fire department and that request and
receive service from the Des Plaines fire department. This subsection A does
not apply to parcels of land that receive service from the Des Plaines fire
department pursuant to a mutual aid fire agreement.
      2.   Fee Structure: The rates for fire and ambulance service to
properties covered by this subsection are as follows:
         a.   Three hundred thirty dollars ($330.00) for responding to a
medical emergency plus one hundred ten dollars ($110.00) per hour for each
emergency medical apparatus utilized to mitigate the emergency and the cost of
all medical supplies used because of said emergency.
         b.   Five hundred fifty dollars ($550.00) for responding to a fire,
rescue or hazardous materials emergency, plus one hundred ten dollars ($110.00)
per hour for each emergency apparatus utilized to mitigate the emergency, the
cost for all damaged, destroyed or spent equipment, the cost for utilizing city
water, and city overtime costs related to said fire, rescue or hazardous
materials emergency.
      3.   Payment: All fees for fire and ambulance service due and owing to
the city pursuant to this subsection shall be paid not later than ten (10) days
after the receipt of notice thereof.
      4.   Limitations: All laws, ordinances, and regulations relating to fire
service within the city in this chapter and in the city fire code, as they may
be amended from time to time, shall be in full force and effect in all
locations to which this subsection applies.
   B.   Ambulance Fees:
      1.   Purpose: Ambulance fees are established for the purpose of defraying
a portion of the costs incurred by the city related to the transportation,
treatment and evaluation of persons by the Des Plaines fire department.
      2.   Ambulance Fees Established:
         a.   Ambulance Service Fee: Each person who receives ambulance
transportation or emergency medical services from the City will be charged an
ambulance user fee in an amount equal to the amount listed in the most recent
Ground Emergency Medical Transport (GEMT) program report reflecting the actual
cost incurred for the treatment and transport of residents and nonresidents, as
appropriate, plus a mileage fee of $15.00 per mile traveled during the
transport of the patient. Specifically, but without limitation, all Advanced
